text:
Introduction to the Second Edition
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
Praise be to Allah alone, and peace and blessings be upon him after whom there is no Prophet.
As for what follows:
This is the second edition of this unique poem after the first edition went out of print. The most important aspect of this edition is the correction of errors that occurred in the first one, especially in the diacritical adjustment (Tashkil) of words; for no matter how much the typesetter tries, something of that is bound to be missed, especially if the book is voweled. Furthermore, I have removed from it what related to Major Sins (Al-Kabair) in the first edition from pages 68-71, after it was proven to me that it is not by Ibn Abd al-Qawi, but rather by Imam Sharaf al-Din al-Hajjawi. It was mentioned and attributed to him by Imam Shams al-Din al-Saffarini in his book (Ghidha' al-Albab li-Sharh Manzumat al-Adab) (1/354), where he said: (...severing ties of kinship is among the major sins, and Al-Hajjawi mentioned it in his poem containing the Major Sins located in his [book] Al-Iqna', and I have explained it in a concise commentary...).
Also, Ibn Humayd al-Hanbali al-Makki mentioned that it belongs to Al-Hajjawi in his book (Al-Suhub al-Wabilah) (3/1135), and Sheikh Ibrahim Ibn Duwayan followed him in that in his book (Raf' al-Niqab 'an Tarajim al-Ashab) (p. 353).

text:
A Word by His Eminence Sheikh Ahmed bin Ghannam Al-Rashid
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
Praise be to Allah alone, and peace and blessings be upon him after whom there is no Prophet, and upon his family and companions.
As for what follows:
The poem of Major Manners (Manzumat al-Adab al-Kubra) by the scholar Ibn Abd al-Qawi, may Allah have mercy on him, is worthy of attention. It was printed previously with its commentary (Ghidha' al-Albab Sharh Manzumat al-Adab). The virtuous brother, the skilled researcher Muhammad bin Nasir al-Ajmi, informed me that the scholar Al-Saffarini did not explain it completely, but rather explained most of its verses. It was printed alone [before], but that edition lacked verification (Tahqiq), as it was filled with typographical errors and others. Therefore, our virtuous brother Muhammad bin Nasir al-Ajmi thankfully undertook its verification in a manner befitting it, adjusting its diacritics, and caring for it with utmost care as much as possible, until it became like the sun in the middle of the day. He clothed it in the garment of beauty and splendor, so it became like a bride surpassing the gazelles in beauty, and in its elevation, it rivaled the distant stars, with illuminating notes as clear as the sun at noon.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Indeed, the poem of Major Manners has gathered immense benefits and important legal rulings. Students of knowledge should take care to memorize it, for it is the desired goal for whoever memorizes and masters it. The Hafiz Sheikh Abdul Rahman bin Muhammad bin Khalaf al-Dawsari, may Allah have mercy on him, used to have it memorized, for he was, may Allah have mercy on him, a miracle in memorization. Our Sheikh, the venerable scholar Muhammad bin Sulayman al-Jarrah (1), may Allah have mercy on him, named him 'Al-Hafiz'.
This, and may Allah send blessings and peace upon our Master Muhammad, and his family and companions.
Ahmed bin Ghannam Al-Rashid Al-Hanbali
Kuwait - Al-Fayha
9 Safar 1418 AH corresponding to 14/6/1997 AD
foot_note: 1. Our Sheikh Al-Jarrah, may Allah have mercy on him, had a great interest in this poem, to the extent that he copied it in his own handwriting, as did his brother the poet Dawood Al-Jarrah. I heard him more than once citing some verses from it, may Allah have mercy on everyone. (The Editor).

text:
Introduction to the Verification
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
Praise be to Allah, Revealer of the Book, and I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, the One, the Bestower, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, may Allah bless him and his family and companions who are adorned with the best morals and manners.
As for what follows:
The scholar, the Imam, the Grammarian Shams al-Din Muhammad bin Abd al-Qawi al-Mardawi has composed [in poetry] the manners and morals that every Muslim should adorn themselves with in their day and night, indeed in all their life and their private and public affairs.
The scholar Sheikh Musa al-Hajjawi, author of (Al-Iqna'), says: (And when he - meaning Ibn Abd al-Qawi - composed the long poem in jurisprudence (Fiqh), he followed it with this poem on manners, following the method of a group of the companions [of the Madhhab] like Ibn Abi Musa, Al-Qadi, Ibn Hamdan in his (Ri'ayah), the author of (Al-Mustaw'ib), and others in following the book with a conclusion on manners; so he followed his book with this poem) (1).
Because of the importance of this poem, Hanbali scholars have taken care to explain and comment on it. Among those who explained it: The scholar and editor of the Madhhab Ala' al-Din al-Mardawi, and the scholar, the seal of the investigators among the Hanbalis, Sheikh Musa al-Hajjawi. Then, it was explained with a sufficient, lengthy commentary by

the oft-turning [to Allah] scholar Al-Saffarini. He collected and encompassed much in this explanation of his, and relied in his explanation on several great volumes from the books of the Madhhab and other sources from the collections of knowledge; however, he omitted a number of verses from the poem. Therefore, I saw it appropriate to publish this majestic poem complete and separate after caring for it and adjusting it; hoping that the people of knowledge and its students will benefit from it.
I ask Allah for success in what He loves and is pleased with, and may Allah bless His Prophet, his family, and his companions and grant them peace.
Muhammad bin Nasir al-Ajmi
The Hanbali Mosque in Salhiyah, Damascus the Guarded
On the twenty-ninth of Muharram al-Haram 1418 AH (1)
foot_note: 1. I wrote this small word in the Hanbali Mosque in front of the pulpit, remembering that Ibn Qudamah, Al-Hajjawi, and Al-Balbani used to preach on the steps of this pulpit, may Allah have mercy on them all. May He return to this nation its ancient glory and past might, and Allah is the One sought for help.

Biography of the Author (1)
He is the Imam, the Jurist, the Hadith Scholar, the Grammarian, Shams al-Din Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Abd al-Qawi bin Badran bin Abdullah al-Maqdisi, al-Mardawi, al-Salihi, al-Dimashqi, al-Hanbali.
He was born in the village of (Marda) one of the villages of Nablus in Palestine, in the year 630 AH. He received his primary education in his village and heard Hadith from the preacher of (Marda)

text:
Description of the Copies Relied Upon in Verification
I had available to me - praise be to Allah - in verifying this blessed poem, three manuscript copies and one printed copy, and this is their description:
1 - A copy from Princeton University in America under number (4566). It consists of 34 pages, with 15 lines per page. It is written in clear Naskh script. The name of the copyist and the year of copying are not mentioned. Perhaps this copy is from the manuscripts of the 8th or 9th century. It is a correct copy that almost aligns with the Zahiriyah copy except for a very small amount. I symbolized it with the letter (B).
2 - A copy from Dar al-Kutub al-Zahiriyah in Damascus under number (186 - General). It consists of 32 pages, with 17 lines per page. It is written in a customary Naskh script with vowel points (Tashkil); however, the copyist was not correct in some places. Its copyist - whose name is not mentioned at the end - finished copying on Friday in the month of Rajab in the year (1189 AH). On its title page, there is an ownership note by legal purchase for Muhammad Abd al-Majid al-Dumani al-Hanbali in the year (1295 AH). It is a good copy, and I symbolized it with the letter (Z).
3 - A copy in the handwriting of the majestic scholar Sheikh Abdullah bin Khalaf bin Duhayan al-Hanbali, which is in my possession. It consists of 6 pages, with 24 lines per page.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
The scholar Ibn Duhayan extracted it from the printed version within (Ghidha' al-Albab) by Al-Saffarini. Note that Al-Saffarini did not explain the entire poem, as we indicated in the introduction. This copy in the handwriting of Sheikh Abdullah was finished in the year 1326 AH. I did not rely on it except to consult it in some places, and I symbolized it with the letter (A).
4 - The Printed Copy
It was printed at the Modern Riyadh Library in Riyadh within a collection without a mention of the printing date. It is a photocopy of an old print that I have not seen. This printed version is full of errors and typos; yet, credit goes to the one who printed it first.
I have taken care of this poem, adjusted it, and edited its text, asking Allah for benefit through it, and He is the Guardian of Success.
***

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners
By Imam Shams al-Din Muhammad bin Abd al-Qawi al-Mardawi al-Hanbali (630 - 699 AH)
Cared for and adjusted by Muhammad bin Nasir al-Ajmi

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
The Imam, Sheikh al-Islam, Pillar of Jurists, the Pious, the Ascetic, the Worshipper ("Shams al-Din Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Abd al-Qawi") said:
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful
1 - With Your praise, O Allah, I end and begin ... For Your praise is a duty upon every existing being.
2 - You are exalted above a peer, and a child, and ... A partner, and what every atheist fabricates.
3 - We affirm without doubt that You are One ... And we believe in the caller to You, Muhammad.
4 - Your Messenger, the purest of those You sent to mankind ... And the best of those You extracted from the best lineage.
5 - Upon him be the blessings of Allah, then His peace ... A prayer for us that decrees eternal success.
6 - And [upon] every Prophet to the people, and it is doubled ... For the most noble creature of the most noble origin.
7 - And his Companions, and the illustrious ones of Banu Hashim ... And whoever is guided by their guidance throughout the ages.
8 - And I bear witness that Allah, there is no Lord but Him ... And I ask Him for pardon and the completion of what was begun.
9 - And a good ending that grants the youth satisfaction ... And conveys him in victory to the most noble seat.
10 - And we praise Him with a praise befitting His bounty ... And we ask Him for sincerity in every intention.
11 - To proceed, I shall compose a collection ... Of the etiquette transmitted from the Best Guide.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
12 - From the radiant Sunnah or from the Book of the One ... Who is sanctified above the sayings of the misguided and deniers.
13 - And from the sayings of the people of virtue among our scholars ... The Imams of the people of peace (Islam), from every glorious one.
14 - Perhaps the God of the Throne will benefit us with it ... And settle us in the Gathering in the best seat.
15 - O you who has desire for knowledge and religion ... Listen with a present, attentive heart.
16 - And accept advice from one compassionate toward people ... Eager to deter mankind from destruction.
17 - For I have a trust from the Hadith ... I will exert my effort to deliver it, so I guide and be guided.
18 - So take it, may Allah guide you, do not neglect it ... For in it are all arranged goods.
19 - I say, beginning in poetry and its composition ... So be a listener to my poem without refutation.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Guarding the Limbs
20 - Indeed, everyone who seeks safety should guard ... His limbs from what Allah forbade, he will be guided.
21 - The harvest of his tongue throws the youth into the Fire ... So maintain control of the tongue and restrain it.
22 - Abandon excess speech, so do not be prolific ... In speech other than the remembrance of Allah, you will be happy.
23 - For excess speech is a hardening ... For the heart of the youth, causing reverence to be distant from it.
24 - For a word may cast its speaker into the Fire ... And releasing one's gaze is more harmful, so restrain it.
25 - And the gaze of the youth, O friend, is the scout of his private parts ... And his tire-er, so lower it as much as you can, you will be guided.
26 - For whoever extends a gaze or commits adultery, his family will be adulterated ... So be chaste, and he will be chaste; the Best Guide said it.
27 - For whoever is chaste out of piety regarding the prohibitions of others ... Protects his family truly, and if he commits adultery, he corrupts.
28 - Even if the act of Zina (adultery) were not a major sin ... And the person of intellect did not fear its consequences tomorrow.
29 - It would be worthy to protect his womenfolk ... By abandoning Zina for fear of retribution as it began.
30 - So listen and guard the limbs, each has a Zina ... But the Zina of the private parts is the Major sin, so count it.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
31 - For Allah has paired Zina with calling upon ... A lord alongside Allah in eternal punishment.
32 - And discipline and punish (Ta'zir) the one who comes to an animal ... And support the one who seduces a beauty against her will [for punishment].
33 - If you kill him, there is no liability ... And whoever sees a youth with a spouse, let him draw,
34 - A sword to kill them, and let him kill them together ... There is no Qisas (retribution) upon him nor blood money.
35 - If this was a claim from him and the guardian denied it ... Let him swear, and affirm the Qisas.
36 - And looking at beardless youths (Amrad) is forbidden with desire only ... And it was said even with fear [of fitnah], and affirm it for dislike.
37 - So beware of youths, do not approach them ... And do not send your gaze among them, but restrain it.
38 - And do not belittle a glance from you ... For within it is an arrow kindled with fire.
***

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Prohibition of Backbiting and Gossip
39 - And slander, backbiting, gossip are forbidden ... And revealing a secret, then restrict cursing.
40 - And obscenity, plotting, foul language, deception ... And ridicule, mockery, and restrict lying.
41 - Except for deceiving disbelievers in their war ... And for weddings or reconciling people in dispute.
42 - And make obligatory the restraining of limbs from the forbidden ... And recommended from the disliked without being harsh.
43 - And it was said that backbiting and gossip are minor sins ... But both are major sins according to the text of Ahmad.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Commanding Good and Forbidding Evil
44 - And make your commanding of good and forbidding, O youth ... Of evil an individual obligation (Fard Ayn), you will be guided.
45 - Upon the one knowing the prohibition and the act, if no one ... Else has undertaken it, with safety from the aggression of an aggressor.
46 - Even if he is immoral and ignorant. And in other than ... What was said to be a communal obligation (Fard Kifaya), limit it.
47 - And scholars are specialized in what knowledge is specific ... To them and by whom they seek victory.
48 - And the weakest of it is with the heart, then his tongue ... And the strongest is the denial of the strong youth with the hand.
49 - And deny upon children every forbidden act ... By disciplining them, and knowledge in the Law comes by repelling.
50 - So whoever strikes children, the strike of a discipliner ... And his wife upon rebellious disobedience.
51 - And the strike of the leader of Muslims upon subjects ... To discipline them by Law, without being harsh.
52 - And the strike of a guardian or teacher of boys ... Without transgression, there is no liability for what was initiated.
53 - And whoever hands over a son to be taught swimming ... And he drowns, he is not liable, like handing over a mature one.
54 - Himself to him to be guided in swimming ... And he drowns. And it was said the son perishes by a distant one.
55 - And if a human orders a non-accountable person ... To go down a well or says to him ascend,

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
56 - To a palm tree, judge with liability for the commander ... But if he was of reason, an adult, then no hand [liability].
57 - And if the authority was the one commanding him to it ... Then there are two views regarding his liability, establish it thus.
58 - And one is liable for causing a pregnant woman to miscarry by discipline ... And whoever caused her to miscarry by medicine for her illness, pay blood money.
59 - And if the Dhimmi openly commits abominations in the Sharia ... He is rebuked, unlike the one hiding in a resting place.
60 - And begin with the easiest, then increase according to need ... If it does not cease with the effective command, then repel.
61 - If you do not fear injustice in that command ... If that denial was confirmed as obligatory.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Ruling on Musical Instruments, Singing, and Poetry
62 - And there is no fine for breaking a cross, nor vessels ... Of silver, nor an eye [idol] for males and females.
63 - And no fine for the tambourine with cymbals if you broke it ... Nor for images either, nor instruments of play (Dad) (1).
64 - And instruments of astrology, magic, and the like ... And tear up books that contain this and its likes.
65 - And eggs and walnuts for gambling, to the extent that ... Removes the intent of corruption from the denounced item.
66 - And slashing wine containers and jugs absolutely ... Even if they are useful for something else in the established view.
67 - And the flute and reed pipe are forbidden, and what ... Resembles them of instruments of diversion and rejection.
68 - Even if singing does not accompany all of them ... And among them are string instruments without restriction.
69 - And the prohibition of singing is what the majority judged ... And from the two Abu Bakrs, an Imam and role model,
70 - Its permissibility, not its dislike. And Imam Abu Ya'la ... Permitted it with dislike, so recite (2).
71 - So whoever becomes famous for it, does it much, and takes ... A singing slave girl for it, is not considered among witnesses.
72 - And there is no harm in permissible poetry, memorizing it ... And composing it; whoever dispraises that transgresses.
foot_note:
1. Meaning: Amusement and play, (Ghidha' al-Albab) (1/ 211).
2. After this verse, there are six verses not found in the manuscripts. Abu Ya'la is Muhammad bin al-Husayn al-Baghdadi, Ibn al-Farra', died in the year (458 AH).

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
73 - For the Chosen One heard the poetry of his Companions ... And their amorous verses without specifying maidens.
74 - And there was no denier of that in any era ... So how [can it be denied] when there is wisdom in it? So narrate and recite.
75 - And affirm the prohibition of satire, praise with falsehood and obscenity ... And erotic verses about specific foreign women.
76 - And describing adultery, wine, beardless youths, and singing women ... And wailing due to discontent is cited [as forbidden].

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Shunning Sinners
77 - And shunning the one who shows disobedience is Sunnah ... And it was said: If it deters him, make it obligatory and confirm it.
78 - And it was said: Absolutely, as long as he is publicizing it ... And meet him with a frowning, dusty face.
79 - And spying on one concealing his sin is forbidden ... And past sin if he does not renew it.
80 - And shunning the one who calls to a misleading matter or ... One causing immorality, mandate it without hesitation.
81 - Except for the one strong enough to refute his saying ... And repel the harm of the misleader with a defense.
82 - And fulfills people's needs by coming to him ... And there is no shunning [allowed] regarding his customary greeting.
83 - And prohibition of denying greeting for more than three [days] ... Confirm it for other than the one we said to shun.
84 - And it is disliked for a person to sit with a vile person ... And with the immoral or the hypocrite, the rejected one.
85 - Likewise with a foolish person, who is one of weak mind ... And with the player of Chess, Backgammon (Nard), and rejection.
86 - And one accused in his religion or honor ... Ibn Hamdan gave fatwa with this, so follow him and imitate (1).
foot_note: 1. Ibn Hamdan is Ahmed bin Hamdan bin Shabib al-Harrani, died in the year (695 AH).

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Greeting, Handshaking, and Permission
87 - And be aware that greeting is for Sunnah ... And your reply is Obligatory, not merely recommended with certainty.
88 - And the greeting of one person from a group suffices ... And the reply of a youth among them on behalf of all, O Adi (1).
89 - And the greeting of the few, the young, the passerby ... And riders upon the opposite, support this.
90 - And if the one ordered to reply among them greets ... Then the Sunnah is achieved since he is an initiator.
91 - And greet when you stand from the presence of a person ... And greet when you come to your house, you follow [the Sunnah].
92 - And your spreading of Salam necessitates love ... From people; aim for the unknown and the known.
93 - And making it definite with the word 'Al-Salam' is permitted ... And making it indefinite [Salam] also according to the text of Ahmad.
94 - And it was said it is disliked, and it was said it is a greeting ... For a dead person. And make the farewell definite like a repeater.
95 - And seeking permission to enter is Sunnah ... Upon others, from relatives and strangers.
96 - Three times. And entering suddenly is disliked ... Especially from a journey and being far away.
97 - And his standing should be facing a door or window ... If he is not answered, he leaves, and if he fears [prying], he increases [distance].
98 - And moving his sandals and showing his sound ... For his entry, witness this even for his own home.
99 - And if a human looks through the crack of his door ... Without his permission, if he pokes out his eyes, no blood money.
foot_note: 1. In (Z): (Ba'idi), and the established text is from (B), the printed version, and (Ghidha' al-Albab).

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
100 - It is the same from a path, or from the property of an observer ... Or from a window, or from a built wall.
101 - Even with the possibility of repelling without it ... And the absence of women or the presence of an aggressing Mahram.
102 - And do not throw at the blind. Abu al-Wafa (1) said ... Yes, if he can hear, let him be thrown at and repelled.
103 - And every standing up, except for a ruler, a scholar ... His parent, or a master, establish its dislike.
104 - And shake hands with every Muslim you meet ... Your sins will scatter as in the Musnad.
105 - And prostration to other than Allah is not lawful for us ... And kissing the ground is disliked with strictness.
106 - And bowing when greeting is disliked from you ... And kissing a person's head is lawful, and on the hand.
107 - And hugging is lawful for the one meeting out of religiosity ... And kissing the mouth is disliked, understand and record.
108 - And withdrawing the hand quickly from one shaking hands ... And for a group to whisper excluding a single person.
109 - And for a person to sit by someone speaking ... Secretly. And it was said: Attend, and if he permits, sit.
110 - And looking at an old woman is not rejected, nor shaking her hand ... And being alone with her, dislike it, but not her greeting, witness this.
111 - And saying 'Yarhamuk Allah' (Tashmit) to her. And dislike both traits for ... The youth of both genders, very far and farthest.
112 - And greeting is disliked upon one occupied ... With Dhikr, Quran, and the saying of Muhammad.
113 - A preacher, one giving a lesson, and those discussing ... Sciences, and one giving a sermon to benefit the monotheist.
114 - One repeating Fiqh, the Muazzin, after him the ... One praying, and one purifying for an act of worship.
115 - And leave the eater, with the one defecating, then the one ... Fighting enemies in a war of deniers.
***
foot_note: 1. Abu al-Wafa is Ali bin Aqil bin Muhammad bin Aqil, Al-Baghdadi, died in the year (513 AH).

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Connecting Ties of Kinship, Kindness to Parents, and Equity between Children
116 - And be a joiner of ties of kinship even to a hater ... You will be increased in lifespan and provision and be happy.
117 - And do not sever ties of kinship, for severing ... A relative is a major sin, distancing from Allah.
118 - So do not join a people where Allah's mercy does not cover them ... A severer resides [there], this has come with a threat.
119 - And improving character and companionship is good ... Especially for the parent, which is emphasized.
120 - Even if he is a disbeliever. And obedience to him is obligatory ... Except in forbidden things or for a confirmed command.
121 - Like seeking knowledge that does not harm them ... And divorcing wives based on mere opinion.
122 - And be kind to his friends after his death ... And execute wills from him in a good manner.
123 - And honor him by your seeking forgiveness if you are righteous ... For this is the remains of his accustomed kindness.
124 - And equity is obligatory between his sons in ... Giving, like inheritance, from every origin.
125 - And a mother with children is like their father ... Make equity obligatory upon her in distribution, you will be guided.
126 - And the father, in prioritizing some of his children ... For a valid intent, is not sinful, rather praised (1).

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
127 - And it is not permissible for a giver to take back a gift ... Even if he was not rewarded, or a completely voluntary giver.
128 - Except the father regarding the first, and a grandfather regarding a distant one ... And a mother according to a view they extracted well.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Prohibition of Astrology, Magic, and Incantations
129 - And do not follow the science of stars except that which ... Guides to a direction and time of worship.
130 - For its limit is knowing eclipses, and there is no benefit ... In it for a person of intellect, nor a good purpose.
131 - And the eclipse of the two luminaries is not a cause ... For anything except frightening us and threatening.
132 - So do not listen to the fear-mongering of every fabricator ... And deny the judgments of the astrologer and reject.
133 - And pray the Eclipse Prayer, for it is ... The most established of what every narrator narrates to us.
134 - And whoever shows magic, like riding ... An inanimate object so it travels under him like a strong horse.
135 - And claiming the gathering of Jinn in obedience to him ... By his incantations wherever he wills, obediently helped.
136 - And that the planets in the sky, according to his claim ... Speak to him; he disbelieves, so cut [him] with the sword.
137 - And two views if nothing appears from his action except ... A mere claim of doing that, attribute it.
138 - And the magician of the People of the Covenant (Dhimma), keep him with the better ... Of maintaining Ibn al-A'sam the rebellious.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
139 - And the one who does magic by fumigation or by medicine or ... By potions, if he does not apostatize, discipline him severely.
140 - And Qisas is taken from him if he committed what warrants it ... And if he does not repent, imprison him, a prison of blocking.
141 - And from him [Ahmad]: Like a fortune teller, let him be imprisoned, and a soothsayer ... Those of magic absolutely without restriction.
142 - And the ruling of those with incantations is the rulings of a magician ... And it was said regarding what benefits the monotheist.
143 - Like dissolving [magic] and incantations, they are tolerated ... For the prohibition is only against the harmful and corrupting.
144 - And the condition of that which they permitted among those ... Is if it was with permissible, customary speech.
***

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Renting Bathrooms, Reading in Them, and Rulings on the Mushaf
145 - And every reading in the Hammam (bathhouse) is disliked ... And verbal Dhikr, and greeting for an initiator.
146 - And the rent of a Hammam is lawful [though] disliked ... Like its price, and the contract is not void.
147 - And raising your voice in supplication or with ... The funeral or in war during intensification.
148 - And dotting and vowel-marking in a speech for a Mushaf ... And do not write other than it in it, and strip it [of extras].
149 - And forbid, and from him dislike, renting a Mushaf ... Like selling, and regarding exchange, attribute two views.
150 - And a prohibition without difference is traveling with a Mushaf ... To a land of wars, like giving ownership to an atheist.
151 - And forbid leaning on that which ... Contains it, along with books of Hadith, and be strict.
152 - And permissible is hiring for copying the Quran and ... Hadith and books of Fiqh and poetry, not rejection.
153 - By a period or estimating its pages with ... Lines and describing the script and margin, limit it.
***

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Oiling, Applying Kohl, Tattooing, and Growing Beards, etc.
154 - And oil yourself intermittently, and apply kohl an odd number of times, you will do right ... Upon every eye in the strong one with Ithmid.
155 - And change grey hair with other than black, and leave it ... And do not pluck it, for it is the light of the monotheist.
156 - And that is the warner of a person announcing his departure ... And dislike Qaza' (shaving part of head) then deception of young women.
157 - Due to a curse upon it, forbid it, like tattooing and filing teeth ... And plucking eyebrows and joining hair with hair, restrict it.
158 - And men removing hair from the face is disliked absolutely ... And shaving the nape also regarding people, so witness.
159 - And growing beards is recommended, and it was said: take what ... Is near the throat along with what exceeds the fist hold.
160 - And cutting, and it was said the best is trimming mustaches ... Contrary to Magians and beardless Rafidis.
***

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Circumcision, Covering Vessels, Clipping Nails, and Blessing the Sneezer
161 - And be knowledgeable that circumcision is obligatory ... With safety in the stronger view, and a decided worship.
162 - And it is legislated that he does not reach ten uncircumcised ... And doing the act of Jews on the seventh [day] is disliked.
163 - And do not circumcise the dead without doubt ... And his mustache and armpit and nail, cut them.
164 - And tying the water skin and covering the vessel is legislated ... And closing doors and extinguishing the fire.
165 - And clipping nails and plucking his armpit ... And aim for shaving or depilatory agents for the pubes.
166 - And its remaining after forty [days] is disliked ... And burying all of it is Sunnah, so narrate and follow.
167 - And perfume with apparent scent is recommended for our males ... And apparent color is sufficient perfume for young women.
168 - And lowering the voice is good from a sneezer and that ... He covers a face for concealment from the bad.
169 - And he praises aloud and let a hearer bless him ... For his praising, and let him show the reply of the returner.
170 - And say to the youth 'May you be healed' after three ... And to the child 'May you be blessed' and order him to praise.
171 - And cover a mouth and suppress, you will do right in yawning ... For that is Sunnah by the command of the Guide.
***

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Medicine and Related Matters, and Warning the One in Whom Greyness Appears
172 - And trusting People of Dhimma is disliked ... For protecting wealth or for its division, witness.
173 - And seeking medical treatment from them is disliked without necessity ... And what they compounded of thickened medicine.
174 - And giving the front seat to a disbeliever in a gathering is forbidden ... And in paths, force him to the narrow part and constrain.
175 - And say 'Wa Alaykum' if some of them greet ... Answering obligatorily, do not allow it for an initiator.
176 - And do not ask about the ruling of their children, and if ... You are asked, say Allah knows best regarding a corrupter.
177 - And there is no harm legally if a Muslim treats you ... And you complain of what you encounter, but begin with praise.
178 - And leaving medicine is better, and your action is permissible ... In what the prohibition of a single component is not certain.
179 - For in sickness and afflictions is the greatest wisdom ... Awakening the person of intellect upon inspection.
180 - The state of affairs calls out: Strive to depart ... From the lean dwelling of much distress.
181 - The warner of greyness came to you with sickness informing ... That you follow the people today or tomorrow.
182 - So take preparation in provision, for death is inevitable ... There is no escape from it nor any deviation.
183 - For this abode of yours is not an abode of residence ... But it is an abode of trial and taking provision.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
184 - Did there not come to you from your Lord {And take provisions} ... So what is the excuse of the one who met Him without provision?
185 - For these days are but stages ... Bringing every distant one closer to the Abode of Meeting.
186 - And whoever travels towards the two obliterated abodes a year ... Then the meeting has drawn near from him, as if it has occurred.
187 - For people are but like travelers following each other ... A resident for a nap following one leaving in the morning.
188 - And whoever Azrael is the guarantor of his soul ... If he misses him today, he will not escape tomorrow.
189 - And whoever's soul in the body is a trust from Him ... Then farfetched is safety hoped for from a returner.
190 - So what is the right of a person of intellect to spend a night ... Without writing a will and the witnessing of witnesses?
191 - And making a will is obligatory on a person if there are ... Upon him rights obligatory to return.
192 - And whoever bequeaths in sin like creating a church ... And writing a Torah and Gospel is rejected.
193 - And a drinker of wine or a singer and the like of this ... Of help in doing sins for an aggressor.
194 - And the bequest of the pious and the sinner is the same ... In this, and the bequest of a Dhimmi and a monotheist.
195 - And there is no harm if the youth hides a shroud for himself ... From lawful means and traces of satisfaction and worship.
196 - So anticipate the attack of death in earning that by which ... You succeed on the Day of Resurrection, and strive.
197 - For how cheated is the one cheated of the blessing of health ... And the blessing of the possibility of earning worship.
198 - So make yourself your own executor, increasing ... For the journey of the Day of Gathering, good provision.
199 - And imagine the arrival at the grave whenever you see it ... Beneficial for yourself, so send it forth, you will be happy.
200 - For nothing benefited the human like his earning ... On a Day when a person flees from every origin.
201 - Sufficient as a deterrent for a person is a definite death ... And a grave and horrors witnessed tomorrow.
202 - And a blazing Fire Allah promised whoever disobeyed ... So among them is one exiting after misery and one eternal.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
203 - And the youth is asked in the grave about his Prophet ... And about his Lord and the Religion, the action of a threatened one.
204 - So whoever Allah makes steadfast answers as a monotheist ... And whoever He does not make steadfast is not a monotheist.
205 - And that, by my life, is the last of the trials which ... When you escape from it, you have won an eternal victory.
206 - So we ask Him for steadfastness in this world and the Hereafter ... And an ending that decrees eternal success.
207 - And announcing death generally is disliked ... 'Attention, Zayd has died', not to the people of affection.
208 - And sitting of comforters beside him is recommended ... Like slaughtering a camel between a weeper and one helped.
209 - And the grave robber is [hand] cut for his taking ... The shrouds from the dead from the custody of a grave.
210 - And beware of prohibited wealth, inheriting it ... You will return with clear loss and grief.
211 - So you will be miserable with it altogether and burn with it in Hell ... While another enjoys it and is happy tomorrow.
212 - And hasten to discharge grievances obediently ... And search the era of youth and inspect.
213 - So woe to you, the most miserable of people, one taking burden ... For others, gathering if you do not take provision.
214 - And prioritize hope over fear at his despair ... And meet your Lord with good opinion, you will be happy.
***

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Visiting the Sick, Prompting the Dead, and Visiting Graves
215 - And visiting the sick is legislated, so go to them ... You will wade in mercy that covers the gatherings of visitors.
216 - For seventy thousand angels of satisfaction ... Pray upon the one who visits the sick until the next day.
217 - And if he visits him at the beginning of the day, they continue ... Upon him the prayer until the night, so attribute it.
218 - So visit them intermittently and lighten [the stay], and among them is ... The one who prefers lengthening from a loving friend.
219 - So think and observe in visiting the condition of whom ... You visit, and do not increase questioning, causing distress.
220 - And remind the one you come to of sincere repentance ... And prompt him at death with the saying of the monotheist.
221 - And (Yasin) if recited, his death is lightened ... And the burden is lifted from him at burial.
222 - And pay the debts of the dead legally and distribute ... The bequest of a just person, then intend his preparation.
223 - And the trustworthy and knowledgeable is chosen for washing ... With the rulings of washing even by following authority.
224 - And do not reveal a secret the dead prefers concealing ... Except for one of immorality and accustomed innovation.
225 - And the surplus of what is collected for a dead person belongs to his owner ... And if they are unknown, spend it on another, you will be guided.
226 - And do not prevent his family from seeing the dead ... And kissing him is the act of the good lover.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
227 - And consoling the afflicted person is a virtue ... Indicated by the supported Hadith.
228 - And every crying that is not accompanied by wailing ... Nor listing virtues [lamenting], the one doing it is not an aggressor.
229 - And tearing the pocket (garment) is forbidden, and slapping afterwards ... Wailing along with lamenting, and count their likes.
230 - And visiting graves is legislated for males ... And regarding the first [visiting], dislike the speech for young women.
231 - And he gifts to them what is easy to do ... Of righteousness and Quran, it benefits the one guided.
232 - And what has been narrated about the visited one regarding his speech ... For how many Mursal and Musnad [hadiths] have come regarding it.
233 - And perfuming graves and lighting lamps on them is disliked ... And repel from kissing them and taking from their soil.
***

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Encouragement to Learn Inheritance Laws and the Ruling on Looking and Related Matters
234 - And people are but dead and delayed ... So knowledge of the one who has died is half for him, intend it.
235 - So hasten to the science of inheritance laws, for it is ... The first knowledge to be erased and lost.
236 - For in establishing the rulings of inheritance is a wisdom ... That guides every directed one to the rulings.
237 - And if a female falls ill and they find no ... Doctor for her except a man, permit him and facilitate.
238 - And whatever contains the ailment from her entire body ... Then judge with looking for the proficient doctor.
239 - And her slave looks at the face of the beauty and the palm ... And the one who has no desire in the confirmed view.
240 - Due to disease, effeminacy, and old age, so analyze ... And there is no covering from a child for young women.
241 - And our female child among men is like our male child ... With women, understand what I say and guide.
242 - And if a female child becomes discerning, then like ... The discerning [boy], the ruling in her applies for the inspector.
243 - And whatever appears from old women ... Whoever looks at it is not distant [from right].
244 - Likewise the ruling in the ugly woman and the face of strangers ... And palms, let him look safely in a distant one.
245 - And everyone has the right to look at his own gender at ... Other than the shameful Awrah, with excess.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
246 - Likewise regarding a Dhimmi woman with a free woman ... With Muslim women, transmit them, the transmission of the most intended.
247 - And does [a Muslim] woman look at what is not apparent ... Usually seen from us? Attribute two views.
248 - And look at the face of the young woman if you are proposing ... And what appears from her usually in the confirmed view.
249 - And from him: at a face. And from him: and her palm ... Like her Mahram without seclusion, keep away.
250 - And a bargainer [buyer] looks at every apparent part ... Usually seen, and the head with the leg of young women.
251 - Likewise in a saying, those with Mahrams ... So be aware and guard yourself and strive.
252 - And it was said: Let him look at other than what is between a knee ... To a navel in the two forms, so restrict.
253 - And restricting this to slave girls is prioritized ... Fearing a hidden intentional defect.
254 - Likewise the ruling of the discerning [boy] without desire ... Otherwise like her Mahram, and from him like a distant one.
255 - And look at the face of the young woman if you are a witness ... Against her, and if you transacted with her, look at it and conclude.
256 - And it is forbidden if the looking is for desire ... At everyone I named in the enumeration.
257 - And everyone has the right to touch all of a wife ... With looking, understand it without restriction.
258 - Likewise the permissibility of slave girls to their master ... And if she is married, he looks at other than the Awrah.
259 - And giving an enema to a person is disliked except for necessity ... And he looks at what the injector needs.
260 - Like a midwife, it is lawful for her to look at ... The place of women's births during delivery.
***

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Cutting Hemorrhoids, Cauterization with Fire, Ruqyah, Hanging Bells, Amulets, Treating with Prohibited Things, and Rulings on Animals
261 - And it is disliked if it doesn't spread, the cutting of hemorrhoids ... And lancing the harm is lawful like a good cutting.
262 - For gangrene spreading in a limb, amputate it if ... You fear its outcome and do not hesitate.
263 - And before the harm, not after it, dislike cauterization ... And from him absolutely without restriction.
264 - Likewise Ruqyah except with verses and what was narrated ... And hanging that is lawful like writing for childbirth.
265 - And every medicine containing a forbidden mixture ... Is forbidden like Theriac without restriction.
266 - And branding animals is lawful on other than the face ... And in the [sacred] months dislike cutting an extended tail.
267 - Like the mane, strictly because of its harm to what ... By your cutting what it defends with, for the distressed one.
268 - And in other than sheep, they disliked castration ... Because of its torture forbidden in a Musnad [Hadith].
269 - And cutting horns and ears and splitting them ... Without harm is changing a customary creation.
270 - And forbid castration of humans, all of them ... Except in retribution from an oppressor and aggressor.
271 - And it is good in Ihram and non-Ihram to kill what ... Harms without benefit like a leopard and snake.

book_title: The Millenary Poem on Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
272 - And crows other than [those of] the crops also and their likes ... Likewise insects of the earth without restriction.
273 - Like bedbugs, fleas, mice, scorpions ... Wasps, snakes, and the like of what is enumerated.
274 - And killing ants is disliked except with harm ... From them, and dislike burning a spoiler with fire.
275 - Even if prohibition was said, then permitted with ... Harm that is not removed except by it, I would not consider it far [from correct].
276 - And throwing fish into fire while not dead is forbidden ... And eat it with what it contains even if not jerked.
277 - And the companions permitted sun-drying their silk worms ... And smoking out wasps and grilling [locusts] with fuel.
278 - And it is disliked due to the Sharia's prohibition to kill a frog ... And shrikes, birds like these two, and the hoopoe.
279 - And water animals are lawful other than frogs ... And crocodile is forbidden in the confirmed view.
280 - And a confined animal is forbidden and the ... Caged bird for the purposes of an aggressor.
281 - And if you see a dead fetus in the belly of the slaughtered ... It is lawful. And forbid the seeds in dung more strictly.
282 - And killing a cat is disliked except with harm ... And if it is owned, then forbid it then, [if it is] not a spoiler.
283 - And what has harm and benefit like a hawk ... And a dog and a cheetah for the economy of hunting.
284 - If it is not property, then you have the choice ... And if it is owned, forbid [killing], and if it harms, then kill.
285 - And what has no benefit nor harm ... Like worms and flies, if it doesn't harm, confirm its dislike.
286 - And what is lawful for the compelled (Mudtarr) is lawful for the coerced (Mukrah) ... And what is not, then no, other than wines more strictly.
287 - And with coercion, the actions of the coerced are void ... Except killing and Islam, then Zina, judge.
***

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
The Ruling on Eating and Mosques
288 - Blowing onto hot food is disliked, as is breathing [into the vessel] ... and the wandering of hands in a single [type of] food.
289 - But if it is of various types, there is no harm, for what ... was forbidden in unity is pardoned in multiplicity.
290 - Eat with three fingers while sitting ... and dislike eating while standing or reclining.
291 - And dislike your eating with two fingers or one finger ... and with a foul smell, dislike coming to a mosque.
292 - Taking, giving, eating, and drinking ... with the left hand, dislike it; and while reclining, add [to the dislike].
293 - If you build a mosque on a wide road ... with the permission of an Imam, it does not harm; you will be guided.
294 - Do not build it without excuse, more emphatically ... so stand with the decrees of the Sharia, you will be guided.
295 - Introducing planting [trees] in a mosque is forbidden ... if you are stopped with its confirmed endowment [conditions].
296 - If it [the mosque] is in no need of their price, then eat ... otherwise, sell it for its repair and return [the money to the mosque].
297 - Whoever builds a mosque for Allah, the Dominant ... with lawful money for bowing and prostrators,
298 - A house will be built for him in the Paradise of his Lord ... so protect it from dirt and bad filth.
299 - And protect it from a speck, or mucus, and spit ... and decoration from silver and gold.
300 - Selling in it is forbidden, then buying it [is too] ... and there are two views regarding the validity of a contracted sale.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
301 - And if a mosque is built between graves ... then forbid it; and in the one built before them [the graves], prostrate.
302 - There is no harm if one prays for a dead person in a mosque ... and the reciting of poetry from what is permissible for a reciter.
303 - And eat sitting upon the left [leg] and keeping upright the ... right one; say Bismillah, then at the end, praise [Allah].
304 - It is disliked to race the people to eat out of greed ... but the master of the house may begin if he wishes.
305 - And before wiping, lick the hand and the vessel ... it will be blessed, and the dish will ask forgiveness for you; rely [on this].
306 - And be one who lifts the food before standing; indeed ... standing before lifting the laid-out food is forbidden.
307 - Gathering the family over provisions increases growth ... for them; and forbid them from eating in isolation.
308 - There is no harm if a young man stores the nourishment of his family ... for a year; and in this, emulate the Prophet.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Hoarding Food and Honoring the Guest and Neighbor
309 - Do not hoard food, for that is forbidden ... and in other than food, it is not forbidden as emphatically.
310 - The condition for prohibition is the restricting of a buyer ... upon the people in a time of severe hardship.
311 - But without harming, it is not forbidden ... like one saving up during cheap prices; witness this possessor of benefit.
312 - And price-fixing is forbidden, for my Lord is the Price-Setter ... and perhaps price-fixing is a cause for increase [in prices].
313 - If you eat at a person's house, then supplicate for him ... for the Guide [Prophet] commanded it and supplicated; bear witness.
314 - Be honoring of bread, not humiliating it ... and make loaves small, and improve the kneading.
315 - Honor your guest and hasten his meal ... and say 'Welcome'; in this, emulate Ahmad [the Prophet].
316 - Every person who endures travel knows the right of the guest ... prolonging the journey in every desert.
317 - He came cold, and the night showing its frown ... aiming for the light of a fire belonging to a good fire-lighter.
318 - So he comforted him with provisions and showed cheerfulness ... and removed the cold from him by preparing a sleeping place.
319 - How great is the difference between this and a man whose guest spent the night ... lying down with hunger, kept awake and sipping [on nothing].
320 - There is no good in one who does not host guests like this ... it was narrated with a chain from the best guide, Muhammad.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
321 - May Allah fight the miser for his stinginess ... for the guest has a provision arriving that will not be decreased.
322 - For the Muslim passing by a brother in villages ... and it was said also in cities and hamlets; like a guided one.
323 - Make hospitality obligatory for a day and a night ... and it was said three [days], and it is recommended with the best [food].
324 - It is not upon him to house him without ... necessity, other than the lack of shelter such as a mosque.
325 - If he fears him, it is not obligatory at all except ... if he is compelled absolutely; and let him be cautious for fear of a corrupter.
326 - Gabriel continued to advise our Prophet ... regarding his neighbors, from relatives and distant ones.
327 - Until he thought the neighbor would inherit, O young man ... and the closest of them is most deserving of kindness, so do good.
328 - Whoever's house towers over the neighbor, must ... build [a screen] that covers the lower one from one seeking to climb.
329 - It is also binding to block a high window even if ... it was there before; and a claim of 'I do not see' do not imitate.
330 - Whoever refuses, force him to build with his neighbor ... if they are equal in height, with the best [solution].
331 - There is no liability in the demolition of a wall feared to fall ... that is harmful; and if it is secured, let the aggressor guarantee it.
332 - Whoever believes in the King, our God ... let him not harm a righteous neighbor, being non-corrupt.
333 - And prevent him from everything harmful to his neighbor ... like a latrine, a bathhouse, and a burning oven.
334 - And a blacksmith's shop, and the beating of bleaching ... and a tannery that harms with a distressing smell.
335 - And from planting that whose roots extend ... to the water well of the neighbor in the established [property].
foot_note: 1. This verse was missing from copy (Z), and affirmed from copy (B) and the printed version.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
336 - Equal are the harmers of self and wealth, O young man ... and hold him liable for what his obstructing action destroyed.
337 - It is disliked to eat the 'Hajm' (uninvited food) if he watches/waits ... with permission; but without it, present him and then expel him.
338 - Smile at the guests and joke over the meal ... to remove from him the embarrassment of the distressed.
339 - Be altruistic if there is scarcity in the provisions ... and do not burden yourself lest you become unable and be blamed.
340 - With the sons of the world, if you eat, be modest ... and with their poor, prefer them, you will be guided.
341 - And with the brothers, if you eat, be expansive ... and socialize, and do not mention words that distress.
342 - Do not tell funny things so they choke ... and do not mention urine or bad filth.
343 - Do not belittle anything presented for hospitality ... and hastening a small amount is an adornment for the one with little.
344 - Eating soil is disliked except for medication ... and eating foul-smelling things unless cooked.
345 - And dislike your eating of the heart's ear (auricle) and glands ... and forbid buying gambling nuts and drive [them] away.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Rulings on Fruits, Jallalah (Filth-eating animals), and Etiquette of Drinking and Sleeping
346 - If a person passes by the fruits of a garden ... without a wall or a watching guard.
347 - Let him eat, but not carry, even from the branches ... and from Ahmad, forbid [taking] from it other than what is fallen/scattered.
348 - And from Ahmad, forbid it absolutely without need ... and with it [need], without penalty, eat but do not take provisions.
349 - There is no penalty on him regarding the permissible ... like eating due to harm [hunger] from a fenced [garden] is excluded.
350 - Do not eat from the milk of an absent person's cattle ... and crops; regarding the grains, the green ones [are forbidden] more emphatically.
351 - Crops or fruits you watered with impurity ... are forbidden, or if you fertilized them [with it], most firmly.
352 - If it was watered after that with pure [water] ... it is permitted; and it was said: dislike it only, do not be harsh.
353 - Whoever's fodder was mostly from impurity ... and it was said: much of it; forbid it emphatically.
354 - Its milk and eggs, forbid them ... and from him [Ahmad]: rather dislike it before confining it [quarantine], imitate [this].
355 - Do not forbid if its fodder was mostly pure ... and do not dislike after a restricted confinement.
356 - Three days, and it is fed pure food ... and it is disliked before confinement if ridden; witness.
357 - Whoever does not intend to slaughter the sacrificial animal quickly ... it is permissible to feed it occasionally with bad impure [feed].

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
358 - Feeding it meat prohibited [for humans] is permissible ... based on his text, with dislike of all [such acts] being emphasized.
359 - Coupling dates and the like is disliked ... and it was said: with sharing, not in solitude.
360 - There is no harm in the youth's satiety when eating ... but extravagance is disliked, and [stopping at] one-third is emphasized.
361 - It is good before wiping to lick fingers ... and eating fallen crumbs by picking them up.
362 - It is good for the youth to make the food morsel small ... and after swallowing, take a second, and chew well.
363 - And picking what is between the places [teeth/fingers] after it ... and cast away and avoid what Allah forbade, you will be guided.
364 - Washing the hand before food and after it ... is disliked with [using] edible things unrestricted.
365 - A person's sleep is disliked before washing ... grease and milk from the mouth and hand.
366 - Eat good things or the opposite, and wear what ... you encounter from lawful things and do not restrict yourself.
367 - What you dislike, leave it without rebuking ... nor faulting provision, and emulate the Lawgiver.
368 - Do not drink from the mouth of the water-skin or the crack of the ... vessel, and look into it, and sip by sucking.
369 - Remove the vessel from your mouth and drink in three [breaths] ... it is more wholesome, healthier, and more quenching for the thirsty.
370 - Taking, giving, eating, and its drinking ... with his left hand, dislike it; and while reclining, increase [the dislike].
371 - Handling harm [filth] with the right hand is disliked ... and its dirt, along with blowing the nose's bad contents.
372 - Likewise removing his sandals with it, and his leaning ... on his left hand behind his back; witness.
373 - Sleeping after Fajr and Asr, or on ... your back and lifting one leg over the other; extend [the prohibition/dislike].
374 - Sitting between the shade and the heat is disliked ... and sleeping on the face of the stretched youth.
375 - Killing the snakes of houses without saying ... three times to it: 'Go safely', is unjust.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
376 - Kill the one with two stripes and the short-tailed snake ... and what is seen after warning or in the desert.
377 - Sleeping on a roof not surrounded ... by a wall is disliked for fear of destruction.
378 - Likewise riding the sea during its turbulence ... and taking women on ships in the text of Ahmad.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Vows, Testimony, Ruling on False Witness and Wine Drinker
379 - Do not make vows, vows are not Sunnah ... due to their absence from every guide and director.
380 - Do not think that vows bring good ... rather vows are the extraction from the stingy tight-fisted one.
381 - The act is not forbidden since fulfillment is recommended ... in the Book of Allah with honest narration.
382 - Be aware that testimony is a position ... of religion to protect rights from rejection.
383 - In it is benefit for both parties; the right of this one ... is preserved, and the conscience of the denier is cleared.
384 - Be cautious of false testimony ... it leads to the wrath of the Dominant [Allah] tomorrow.
385 - And it necessitates for the one who commits it a standing in the ... Hellfire; Ibn Majah narrated this, trace it back.
386 - How often the Guide warned the people against testimony ... of falsehood, with threats that came and warnings.
387 - Did he not say false speech is the highest major sin ... along with Shirk in the text of the two Sahihs? Record it.
388 - So four [people] perish by falsehood: himself ... and the oppressor, the oppressed, and the judge; be deliberate.
389 - Sufficient as a deterrent from that for every rational person ... is the fall of the false witness from the eyes of witnesses.
390 - Taking wages is forbidden in both cases [performing/testifying], and it was said: no ... for poverty; and it was said: if they specified, then follow the performance.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
391 - Whoever has knowledge of a Hadd (punishment) of his Lord ... then leaving harm is better, but if he wishes, let him testify.
392 - And if it is a claim [of rights], the reverse; if you fear abundance of ... obscenity or he refuses advice, then obligate it with the best.
393 - It is recommended for guidance, not for reward ... witness every contract other than what is obligatory.
394 - Forbidding the testimony of a youth regarding other than what ... he knows at the times of request, imitate this.
395 - Reject the singer and the jester with those of ... mockery and the dancer; be guided and directed.
396 - And the player of chess and backgammon for his doing the ... forbidden, and the player of cooing pigeons.
397 - If he toys with them or gambles ... and steals, prevent him from testimony and reject.
398 - Whoever keeps them for company or their chicks ... or letters is not prevented due to the validity of purpose.
399 - And the revealer of secrets regarding intercourse and the like ... and the unveiler of what is customarily protected in public.
400 - And whoever enters the bathhouse without a waist-wrapper ... and eats among people what is not customary.
401 - And whoever stretches his legs without necessity ... and addresses women with obscenity in a gathering.
402 - And the claimer of gathering Jinn, then the astrologer ... and the geomancer, or story-teller, and the renter of the rejected.
403 - And the player of swings and weight lifting and the ... racer in swimming and customary running.
404 - If play contains compensation from the ... sides or from some of them, forbid it and block it.
405 - That is gambling (Maysir); regarding avoiding it ... the command came in the Quran, a threatening command.
406 - If it is free of betting, some of it is forbidden ... like backgammon and chess and count their likes.
407 - And it was said: dislike chess, do not forbid; so by ... excess in it reject him, not by a little.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
408 - There is no harm in play without harm or ... baseness in it like the customary fencing.
409 - Beware of drinking wines, for they ... blacken the face of the servant today and tomorrow.
410 - Indeed, drinking wine is a major sin ... removing the attributes of the guided human.
411 - He is joined with cattle, nay he is lower ... confusing his actions, unguided.
412 - Every observer mocks him due to the evil of what ... he witnesses of his confusion and dissipation.
413 - It removes modesty from him and takes away wealth ... and drops into obscenity and the killing of the brawler.
414 - All attributes of blame are gathered in it ... thus it was named the Mother of Vice; attribute this.
415 - How many verses inform of its prohibition for one who ... contemplates the verses of the Glorified Book.
416 - The Chosen One has cursed nine regarding wine ... Abu Dawood narrated it from the best guide.
417 - And the Lord of the Throne swore He would surely punish ... for it; Ahmad narrated it from Muhammad.
418 - What has come regarding its prohibition reaches, if ... you contemplate it, the level of Tawatur; be guided.
419 - Every Muslim has agreed on its prohibition ... so declare Kafir the one who permits it, and make him eternal in the Fire.
420 - Addiction to it is one of the major sins, so avoid ... perhaps you will attain success and be guided.
421 - A little of it is forbidden like a lot of it ... and it is not a cure, rather it is the disease; keep away.
422 - For Allah the Great did not make our cure ... in what is forbidden in the religion of Ahmad.
423 - Every drink, if a large amount intoxicates ... a little of it is forbidden; count it as wine.
424 - From whatever thing it was, it is absolutely forbidden ... even if it was cooked without restriction.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
425 - Except for the thirst of the desperate if mixed with what ... quenches; and for the one choking, add by consensus.
426 - Prohibition is not established in what you brewed (Nabidh) ... just before three [days]; drink it as long as it doesn't foam.
427 - There is no harm in Fuqqa' (barley water/beer) as it is not intoxicating ... nor leading [to it], but if he keeps it, it spoils.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Masturbation, Oaths, Slandering Chaste Women and Its Consequences
428 - Punish (Ta'zir) whoever masturbates without fearing Zina ... nor harm to his body, and threaten.
429 - And from Ahmad: rather in it, with lack of fear ... is dislike of propriety (Makruh Tanzihi) without strictness.
430 - Al-Banna transmitted the Takfir of whoever holds the view of ... insulting the Companions of the Prophet Muhammad.
431 - Beware of the false oath, for it ... surely necessitates Allah's wrath if intentional.
432 - Obligate [oaths] to save a perishing person from injustice ... and recommendation for a recommended act to reform a corrupter.
433 - Whoever swears a lying oath to cut off ... the right of a person, anger will be upon him and he will be distanced.
434 - There is nothing in the Ila' (oath of abstinence) of the one in the right with certainty ... and if he ransoms the Ila', it is more pious; so do good.
435 - Do not make Allah a shield for yourself ... with lying oaths like the hypocrite, transgressing.
436 - Increasing and excess of the truthful ... oath is disliked for fear of lying upon repetition.
437 - Whoever's breaking [of oath] is better, it is Sunnah ... and recommended before the Judge for the rightful owner to ransom.
438 - There is no harm in his oaths with his truthfulness ... and interpretation (tawryia) does not benefit every aggressor.
439 - Forbid, and it was said dislike, swearing by other than the ... God; whether you attributed to him or did not restrict.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
440 - Expiation is not obligatory for the breaking of a swearer ... except the one swearing by Allah, my Lord and Originator.
441 - Oaths of the non-competent (Mukallaf) are not binding ... [even if] intending its consequence, even if not accustomed.
442 - Recommendation, and it was said obligate, fulfilling the oath of a swearer ... without harm; or outwardly show it, imitate.
443 - Whoever seeks means (Tawassul) by the God, answer, you will be right ... without harm, what the best Guide enacted.
444 - Indeed, slandering chaste women is a major sin ... the text came regarding its gravity with threat.
445 - O Nation of the Guide, will you not desist from ... sins in which is the confinement of customary modesty?
446 - That is the consequence of injustice from every oppressor ... and the consequence of Zina, then Usury and excess.
447 - It encompasses with what the punishment reaps others besides us ... here and tomorrow; every aggressor suffers by it.
448 - The slanderer of the Mother of the Chosen One, kill him absolutely ... even if he was a Muslim or a Jew.
449 - And his slanderer too, and that is apostasy ... and Islam does not drop killing, most emphatically.
450 - If he was a disbeliever then accepted Islam, spare him ... in the first [instance], and with Allah he who is guided succeeds.
451 - Whoever repents from slandering a person before his knowledge ... and his analyzing (forgiving), is not absolved in the confirmed view.
452 - Fear Allah regarding oppressing people and beware of it ... and fear the Day of the oppressors biting on the hand.
453 - Do not think Allah is unaware of that ... but He gives respite to whom He wills until tomorrow.
454 - Do not be deceived by forbearance toward the oppression of an oppressor ... He will seize him with a severe seizure and with power.
455 - Indeed, oppressing people is a grave sin ... the text came regarding its prohibition with threat.
456 - Forgiveness is hoped for other than oppression tomorrow ... and if the oppressed wishes, he takes retribution tomorrow.
457 - Whoever was stingy with his wealth in the world ... how will he be on the Day of eternal punishment?
458 - Do not be deceived by who is forgiven in the worlds ... and fulfill the rights of people, you will be safe and guided.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
459 - If a person's debt is by consent ... when not fulfilled, it remains; how then with a witness?
460 - Whoever kills the adulterer with his wife, there is no ... retribution (Qisas) upon him regarding the wrongdoer nor blood money.
461 - If the guardian does not believe him nor does he bring ... evidence of the aggression, make him liable and guide.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Killing Unjustly and Its Consequences and Returning to Allah Almighty
462 - Beware of intentional killing of a believer unjustly ... for that is, after Shirk, the greatest corruption.
463 - Sufficient as a deterrent from it is the threat of the Capable ... with Fire and Curse then eternal abode for the aggressor.
464 - For Abdullah [Ibn Abbas] has spoken regarding it interpreting ... negating the repentance of the intentional killer.
465 - And his eternal abode in the Fire without exit ... and other than him said: if he is recompensed, he is eternal.
466 - Otherwise, Allah's pardon for other than a polytheist ... is vast as He informed in numbered verses.
467 - You seek forgiveness from Allah the Great with repentance ... and raise the palm of the exhausted seeker of aid.
468 - And pray the prayer of the humble with desire ... the prayer of a drowning person alone in the darkness of the night.
469 - For the One you call upon provides for the one who disobeyed ... and is the Opener of a door for the obedient and the aggressor.
470 - But sincerity of hope is the keys of the ... treasures, so call and seek the Bounty and strive.
471 - And say with brokenness knocking on the door of a Merciful ... Near, Responsive, Who begins with favors.
472 - My God, the sinners have come to Your door as a refuge ... hoping for pardon from You, my Lord and Master.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
473 - To You we have fled from Your punishment in dread ... so do not drive us away from Your side, and make happy.
474 - We called You for the matter which You are guarantor ... of answering, O You who never breaks a promise.
475 - To You we have extended our palms with hope ... far be it from You to return the youth empty-handed.
476 - Whoever weeps from fear of Allah, say to him ... you have extinguished a blaze and acquired all worship.
477 - For an eye that wept from fear of Allah is forbidden ... to the Fire in the text of the correct Hadith.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Prayer and Related Matters; Whoever Denies It or a Pillar of Islam, or Denies Allah's Lordship, Mocks Him, or Claims Prophethood
478 - Maintain the five prayers, for they ... are the most emphasized obligation on every guided person.
479 - There is no license in leaving them for a competent person ... and the first thing one is held accountable for tomorrow.
480 - By neglecting them, a person necessitates his joining ... with Pharaoh along with Haman in the worst abode.
481 - Our Prophet continued to advise regarding prayer ... at death until the tongue became weary of speech.
482 - Order the seven-year-olds with it, and at ten, strike ... and from him [Ahmad]: thus obligate them and be strict.
483 - And obligate their guardian to order them with it ... and validate the prayer of the conscious among them, you will be right.
484 - Missing it or part of it by a competent person ... is forbidden except for combining or a missing condition.
485 - Whoever denies the obligation, declare him Kafir if he wills ... in the Abode of Guidance among the people of worship.
486 - Likewise everything agreed upon regarding its ruling when ... it is apparent, not the hidden remote one.
487 - So whoever denies the Pillars or the prohibition of Zina ... and wine, and denies the lawfulness of water and bread.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
488 - And their likes from apparent rulings agreed ... upon; for ignorance, inform him and guide.
489 - So whoever does not repent or is not ignorant of the like ... regarding what he denied, he disbelieves; so cut with the sword.
490 - And the abandoner of one of the five out of laziness, and his fasting ... and Hajj, Zakat, intending eternal abandonment.
491 - And postponing it while thinking death comes before it ... if he does not repent, kill him as a disbeliever according to the furthest [view].
492 - Whoever denies the Creator or an Attribute of His ... or some of the Books of the One God.
493 - Or the Messengers, or whoever insults Him or His Messenger ... even if joking, he disbelieves like the intentional one.
494 - And one who mocks Allah or a verse of His ... or the Messengers, declare him Kafir and punish even if guided.
495 - Claiming a partner or a father or a consort ... for Him or a child; count all this as Kufr.
496 - A claimant to Prophethood also disbelieves ... and everyone who assists in believing him disbelieves.
497 - Whoever makes lawful the forbidden without ambiguity ... regarding life and wealth, declare him Kafir, you will be guided.
498 - If he made it lawful by interpretation ... there is no Kufr until it is clarified by a guide.
499 - Whoever eats pork or the like, do not ... declare him Kafir, O this one, by mere eating.
500 - Whoever shows Islam while Kufr is internal ... that is a Zindiq (heretic); when he repents, reject [or accept].
501 - Likewise the ruling of one whom they declared Kafir due to his magic ... and one whose Kufr repeats after being guided.
502 - Whoever insults the Lord of Creation or a Messenger of His ... confirm the killing of these without hesitation.
503 - From Ahmad: accept the repentance of the group if ... truthfulness appears to you, like original Kufr, be guided.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Adhan, Voluntary Prayer, Quran Recitation, and Friday Prayer
504 - Say like the Mu'adhin when you hear him ... and say 'Hawqala' (La Hawla...) when he says 'Hay'ala' (Come to prayer...), you will be rewarded and guided.
505 - Upon finishing it, ask for Wasila ... for the best of mankind, you will be given intercession tomorrow.
506 - After the call, before the Iqamah, supplicate ... the supplication is answered in this without hesitation.
507 - Of the best of it is that you ask for pardon, O young man ... and well-being in this world and the Hereafter; strive.
508 - The virtue of a person's Adhan exceeds Imamate ... and the reverse was said; choose and do well.
509 - The best of a person's voluntary prayer is at night in his house ... so stand after half like David, and prostrate.
510 - Do not leave the night empty of an obedient one's Wird (portion) ... with your Hizb reciting silently, improving it.
511 - If you wish, recite aloud in it as long as you don't fear harm ... to drive away Satan and wake the sleepers.
512 - Take the amount of the soul's capacity, do not bore it ... and take a nap to help with sleep for Tahajjud.
513 - If you do not pray, remember Allah striving ... and repent and ask relief from what you committed, and be right.
514 - There is no good in a servant who sleeps until Duha ... is he not shy of a Master who is Watchful in observation?
515 - Calling him: Is there a requester to be given his request ... and a seeker of forgiveness to be forgiven and supported?

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
516 - Finish [the Quran] in seven [days], it is better, and do not increase ... over a third in a day, you will hit the Sunnah of Ahmad.
517 - For a little with the contemplation of a reciter ... is more pious, so do not rush like poetry and narrate quickly.
518 - Do not recite, if you lead, contrary to what ... the people of that time are upon; you will be detested and distanced.
519 - Avoid Hamza and Al-Kisa'i's letter (recitation style) ... for both are disliked in the confirmed [view].
520 - Reading with melodies like singing is disliked ... and if you change a letter, forbid and be strict.
521 - Read however you wish without ritual impurity ... and with purity is better, and dislike the bad place.
522 - Substituting speech with a verse is forbidden ... benefitting the one you addressed to attain a goal.
523 - Delaying completing [the Quran] beyond forty [days] is disliked ... without excuse according to the text of Ahmad.
524 - If he fears forgetting it, forbid; and it is Sunnah ... to complete in the beginning of the night in winter, O Adi.
525 - In summer, reverse; then gathering his family ... at the completion is beloved, and he supplicates and praises.
526 - Prostration is prescribed for gratitude for a pure person ... for repelled evil or renewed favor.
527 - Pray the Istikhara prayer if you intend a matter ... and if you supplicate afterwards with the reported [Dua], you will be guided.
528 - Whatever need arises, pray and supplicate ... for how many Mursal and Musnad [hadiths] came regarding this.
529 - Maintain six [Rak'ahs] between the two 'Isha's (Maghrib/Isha) ... and pray with Tasbih as came, you will be praised.
530 - Cutting voluntary prayer without need is disliked ... and from Ahmad: forbidden like a confirmed obligatory [prayer].
531 - Hasten to erase sins with the two Rak'ahs of ... Repentance as came, and supplicate, you will be guided.
532 - Indeed, the pillar of religion is sincerity of intention ... otherwise, one turns away with fatigue, empty-handed.
533 - Beware of preceding the Imam, for it is ... the snatching of Satan during worship.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
534 - He strove in negligence, then when you disobeyed him ... he rectified by striving in arts of corruption.
535 - In the five [prayers], bind men in the most correct view to the ... congregation, not a slave; and [as] a condition most emphatically.
536 - The prayer of old women in congregation is not disliked ... with us, rather for the sake of benefit.
537 - A person's supplication after his prayer is recommended ... whatever he wills for the world and religion; so strive.
538 - Beware of negligence in Friday [prayer] by which ... the Lord of the Throne distinguished the nation of Ahmad.
539 - In its day, He gives increase to a winner ... so he sees Him without 'how'; so record.
540 - In leaving it without excuse three times ... rust covers the heart of the heedless distanced one.
541 - Ghusl is prescribed on its day when intending it ... and perfume, cleaning, and wearing new clothes.
542 - And coming early walking, approaching his Imam ... praying and increasing in arts of worship.
