543 - Supplicating and reading Surah Al-Kahf, increasing ... prayers upon the best of mankind, Muhammad.
544 - No one steps over people except their Imam ... or seeing an empty place in the confirmed [view].

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Zakat, Fasting, and Related Rulings
545 - Take the knowledge of Zakat rulings, the peer of Prayer ... in the verses of the Glorified Book.
546 - Sufficient for you in its preference is the benefit of others ... by conquering desire whose whisper is not repeated.
547 - Separating what you love in compliance by giving it ... releases the youth from seventy blaming jaws.
548 - Pay the Zakat of wealth while alive, willingly ... and do not leave it for gloaters and enviers.
549 - It is prescribed for your relatives who are not heirs ... according to needs and closeness, to be supported.
550 - After them, prioritize the scholar and neighbor ... and observe those with needs and modesty, you will be guided.
551 - Paying it to his partner is not sufficient ... nor to whom he supports from relative or distant one.
552 - Nor the shroud of the dead, nor for their debts ... nor like blocking a breach or repairing a mosque.
553 - It is strictly forbidden to protect his wealth with it ... or repel blame or to acquire praise.
554 - That is voluntary charity secretly with surplus ... from the self along with the confirmed sustenance of the family.
555 - It is Sunnah, and in needs or their month of fasting ... and for the neighbor and relatives, even if they harm; emphasize.
556 - He sins in harming self and dependents ... and delaying a creditor in demanding payment, procrastinating.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
557 - If you are patient and have good trust ... and leave asking, give all of it if you wish.
558 - Otherwise, you sin by giving all of it ... and restricting the unaccustomed is disliked.
559 - Allow a person to ask for what is permissible to take ... and from him [Ahmad]: forbid regarding the one with dinner and lunch; imitate.
560 - What comes without looking forward to it or asking ... is Sunnah, and acceptance is not obligatory most emphatically.
561 - It is disliked with looking forward to it; and permissible ... upon Kufr is giving charity in the text of Ahmad.
562 - Take in explaining Fasting without falling short ... a secret worship contrary to accustomed nature.
563 - And patience for losing the familiar from the state of childhood ... and weaning from the beloved and habitual.
564 - So He fulfills the ancient promise for the one who ... Fasting is His, He rewards without breaking a promise.
565 - Maintain the month of Fasting for it is ... the fifth pillar of the religion of Muhammad.
566 - The gates of Hell are closed when it comes ... and the gates of Paradise are opened for the happy.
567 - Punishment is lifted from the people of graves ... and every aggressive devil is chained in it.
568 - Provision is expanded in it for all creation ... and doing every act of worship becomes easy in it.
569 - The Gardens of Bliss and their Hoor are decorated ... for the people of satisfaction in it and the people of Tahajjud.
570 - Allah the Great distinguished it with a night ... favored over a thousand months, so let it be watched for.
571 - Rub in dust the nose of the one cutting the month in negligence ... and honor the reward of the sincere worshiper.
572 - Stand its night and cut your day fasting ... and protect its fast from every distortion and spoiler.
573 - Abandoning false speech among people is obligatory ... but from a fasting person, it is confirmed.
574 - If he is insulted, legislate his saying 'I am fasting' ... to remind self or to preach to an aggressor.
575 - Whoever fears hunger, thirst, or ... harm of lust, breaks fast and makes up, and pays no ransom.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
576 - If you seek the highest Fasting voluntarily to fast ... then a day and a day, aim for David's fast.
577 - And from every month, fast its three white [days] ... and a Thursday then the Mondays; intend.
578 - And following the month of Fasting with fasting six ... suffices for a year, consecutive or separated.
579 - Fasting the Day of Arafah suffices for two years ... and attribute regarding the Day of Ashura with a year.
580 - In Arafat, breaking fast is prescribed for strength ... for supplications at the best scene.
581 - Fasting the Ten and the month completely is prescribed ... if you seek, so the Muharram, continue it.
582 - If you restrict, fast its tenth, then if it is easy ... its ninth with the tenth, or follow this.
583 - Perpetual fasting and Saturday alone are disliked ... and singling out Rajab and Friday alone.
584 - Completing voluntary [fast] absolutely is good ... and allow breaking it; if you make up, do well.
foot_note: 1. This verse fell from (Z), and affirmed from (B) and the printed version.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Hajj, Jihad, Related Matters, and Repelling the Aggressor from Family and Wealth
585 - Hasten with the life's obligation before its expiry ... with Hajj to the Ancient House, emphasized.
586 - Hajj is nothing but the Intent, a specific intent ... worship of submission and pure devotion.
587 - Hearts whose supplication is answered yearn ... for the Truthful, the Pious, the Friend [Abraham], the Glorified.
588 - He came with a specific [call] in the supplication, partial ... and had he generalized, longing would have flown with people immediately.
589 - Hearts yearn for the landmarks of Mecca always ... going and returning to the Caller.
590 - Men and riders on every lean mount ... answering the Call of Truth from every source.
591 - Longing flies with them to that Sanctuary ... to obtain the promise of benefit in the best scene.
592 - For all of them, a dear self became easy ... and family and wealth from new and old.
593 - They accepted crossing deserts over extended shade ... where the expert remains unguided.
594 - Hot wind in a featureless desert was sweet to them ... alongside what they seek.
595 - The scorch of midday heat becomes easy for them ... like the desertion of a lover hoping for a true promise.
596 - Every lover who met desertion with contentment ... will harvest what pleases him from every goal.
597 - How many of easy living, love moved him ... so he stood with burdens of hope, hungry and thirsty.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
598 - Nothing bends his resolve from his quest ... when the Caller announced the connection of maidens.
599 - Sleep flew from them hoping for their union ... and longing for the grave of the Prophet Muhammad.
600 - May Allah forgive me, how often I bid farewell traveling ... to him, while my sin imprisons and binds me.
601 - I carried burdens weighing down my rise ... but I hope for the overlooking of my Master.
602 - My thought of the Generous is beautiful, and my provision ... is the Intercessor of mankind in the standing of Gathering tomorrow.
603 - Even if destinies bent my resolve from travel ... my longing for him is constant and confusing.
604 - My hope is that He grants a visit ... so I reach my goal from those rites.
605 - And kiss the traces of the Prophets humbly ... and spread my palm for supplication and strive.
606 - Whoever performs Hajj with forbidden wealth repeats it ... likewise an apostate who returned, more emphatically.
607 - Abandon obscenity and sin, and likewise ... arguing, and reduce your speech, you will be praised.
608 - Mecca is more deserving of preference, and from him: nay ... the city of the best of creation, the resting place of Muhammad.
609 - Raise both your hands upon seeing the Kaaba ... magnified, high, and say Takbir and Tamjid.
610 - Call with a humble heart, supplicating ... whatever you wish of all Dua without transgression.
611 - Ask Him for acceptance of Hajj and pardon, and call Him ... say Takbir and Tahlil facing the Black Stone.
612 - It is recommended for him to enter the House barefoot ... and increase voluntary prayers in it and worship.
613 - Glance at it as much as possible there with his eye ... and increase performing Umrah and strive.
614 - Drink from Zamzam whatever you wish, indulging ... say Bismillah and ask what you seek and take provision.
foot_note: 1. May Allah forgive the poet, would that he had not mentioned such speech. See the following comment on p. 82.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
615 - Upon leaving, perform the Tawaf of Farewell ... and stand afterwards between the Door and the Corner [Multazam], be guided.
616 - Call a Generous One who invited His delegation to ... His prizes in His House, so call and strive.
617 - Say: O my God, we have come to You hoping for ... promises of truth from a Generous Accistomer.
618 - This is the station of those seeking refuge from Hellfire ... by Your pardon, O Bestower, O Coverer.
619 - By Your aid we came over every subjected thing ... so grant satisfaction, O Lord, before distancing.
620 - This is the time of marching from Your House which ... we leave unwillingly; whenever You wish, we ransom.
621 - A separation of necessity, not a separation of asceticism ... nor desire away from it nor from You, my Master.
622 - We have no desire, praise be to Allah ... other than You; so we have become rich with provision.
623 - Do not make it the last covenant between us ... and ease the travel for us in every desert.
624 - Ask all that you desire of religion and world ... you will attain it whenever you call with true intent.
625 - Send blessings upon the best of Prophets whenever ... you supplicate, it will be another [means] to achieve the goal.
626 - After finishing Hajj, intend a visit ... to the best of creation with his two bedfellows, so aim.
627 - Touching the grave is disliked, O friend, absolutely ... stand facing Qibla and limit the pulpit to the left.
628 - Send blessings and peace in the sanctuary of his shrine ... upon them and ask seeking intercession by Muhammad.
foot_note:
1. May Allah have mercy on the poet, he followed what the later scholars of the Madhhab followed, and they have no proof for the correctness of what they said. Whatever hadiths narrated regarding visiting his grave (peace be upon him) are all weak by consensus of scholars, rather fabricated. Setting out solely to visit his grave (peace be upon him) is not permissible by consensus of the people of the preferred centuries. As for his mosque, it is one of the best deeds. If a Muslim enters the Prophetic Mosque, he greets the Prophet (peace be upon him) and his two companions (from the margin of the printed version).
2. Like saying: O Allah, grant intercession to Your Prophet regarding me. Likewise seeking intercession by his love and following him. As for by his essence (peace be upon him), none of the Salaf said it (from the margin of the printed version).

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
629 - Upon him is Allah's blessing then His peace ... and his Companions and the Family from every noble one.
630 - Jihad against Kufr is a collective obligation ... and after the obligation, it excels every worship.
631 - Because in it is fortification of Ahmad's religion ... and the virtue of general benefit over the restricted.
632 - To Allah belongs he who sold his self to Allah ... and a youth's generosity with self is the utmost generosity.
633 - Whoever goes out, if he gains spoils, it is reward and spoil ... and if he perishes, he wins eternal bliss.
634 - No doer of good desires return when he dies ... except the martyrs so they may strive in increase.
635 - For the virtue of what they were given and attained of satisfaction ... exceeds wishes in eternal bliss.
636 - Sufficient is that they are alive with Allah; their soul ... goes and returns in the Gardens of Bliss.
637 - A morning or evening journey of a Mujahid ... is better than the world by the saying of Muhammad.
638 - Expiated from the seeker of martyrdom on land is everything except ... the rights of people; and everything in the sea; so strive.
639 - The Chosen One was asked about the pain of their killing ... he said: he sees it like a single pinch.
640 - The wounds of Allah's warriors, their bleeding colors ... are blood, and like musk is their scent wafting tomorrow.
641 - The dust of Jihad does not gather in a person's nostril, O youth ... with the smoke of Hell of the thirsty.
642 - Like one who fasted and did not break, and stood and did not sleep ... is the Jihad of the youth in virtue when counted.
643 - How different is the one lying in his bed ... and the wakeful-eyed whose night is on a barren [horse back].
644 - Defending the people of guidance and their sanctities ... and their wealth with self, wealth, and hand.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
645 - Whoever fights enemies to elevate our religion ... this is in the path of Allah, no other; record.
646 - Naval raids excel desert raids ... and with a corrupt [leader] take precaution, so raid like a guided one.
647 - Whoever seeks a person's life or his wealth or the ... harem, beast or youth seeking rejection.
648 - Obligate defense of the harem for the capable, not ... of wealth; and cite two views regarding life.
649 - Our Sheikh preferred surrender during civil strife (Harj) ... and verify the defense against the thief and imitate immunity.
650 - He defends with the least when he thinks he can repel him ... with that; otherwise let him increase and be severe.
651 - Start with advice, then hit with a stick ... if it does not avail, cut him with the sharp [weapon].
652 - Fight him with arrows if you fear his plot ... if he comes close, defend with whatever you wish and drive away.
653 - If you hit him after sufficiency of his evil ... you are liable for what arises from the excess.
654 - There is nothing [penalty] regarding the aggressor killed while attacking ... and whoever killed the aggressor is to be counted a martyr.
655 - There is no difference between the thief entering his house ... and one attacking aggressively in a desert.
656 - Nor between his minimal wealth and much of it ... and whoever defended the compelled person is an aggressor.
657 - Obligate in the stronger [view] defense of her wealth for the one ... compelled to it like eating from it with the best.
658 - It is binding on one capable of repelling an aggressor ... against another to repel for safety from destruction.
659 - There is nothing in what aggression permitted killing ... competent person or animal, fools and ...
660 - No fine in the killed for repelling his evil ... if the killer did not neglect in excess.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
661 - Whoever ties an animal in narrow ... paths, let him guarantee what it destroyed; do not restrict.
662 - Two views regarding absolute [liability] if it was wide ... likewise in acquiring a biting dog in the best [view].
663 - Likewise the ruling in a cat hunting birds, not ... if it urinated in something and licking of the initiated.
664 - If a person lights a fire in his property ... and runs his water on it without aggression.
665 - There is no fine of damaged [property] to his neighbor ... by it, except with his negligence and excess.
666 - Creating what is harmful to his neighbor is prevented ... and he guarantees what he destroyed with renewed prohibition.
667 - No fine in throwing [water] in a passage in muddy [ground] ... and its likes from beneficial non-harmful.
668 - The creator of what harms a path guarantees ... and from melon peels and spilled water.
669 - Whoever brings a person in to host him ... and he falls into a well at his place not marked.
670 - And he did not see due to blindness or its covering ... guarantee him as long as the man did not warn; be guided.
671 - Whoever usurps land, forbid entry to it ... to other than the owner of the land if fenced; emulate.
672 - If not fenced, entry into it is permissible ... and taking grass from it according to Ahmad's text.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Usury, Loan, Endowment, and Manumission
673 - Beware, beware of Usury, for a dirham ... involves punishment more severe than your Zina with buxom women.
674 - Wealth of Usury is obliterated even if it grows ... and a little of the lawful grows in true promise.
675 - Its eater with its feeder with its scribe ... cursing them came regarding it along with witnesses.
676 - If you lend something, it is double recommended ... like two times except five [part] giving of generosity.
677 - If you borrow, be best in repayment to a lender ... for the best of people is the best in return.
678 - Borrowing is disliked for the one bad in repayment ... and for the easy one there is no harm, and emulate the Lawgiver.
679 - How excellent is lawful wealth for one guided ... to spending in accustomed doors of righteousness.
680 - That is Allah's bounty He gives to whom He wills ... and of a man's best righteousness is perpetual endowment (Waqf).
681 - If a youth's acts of righteousness cease, it comes ... to him as a companion at the loneliness of the solitary.
682 - Of the greatest recommended acts is manumission, and best is ... male slaves; and from him: nay, female slaves for maidens.
683 - It is worthy to strive for freeing a slave ... to be freed from the Fire of Hell and emulate.
684 - Recommended without dispute is freeing a religious ... strong one with earnings, trustworthy in solitude.
685 - Do not be a hoarder, preventer, multiplier ... and hasten to spend wealth in obligation and begin.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Earning Lawful Wealth, Avoiding Unlawful, and Blaming Miserliness
686 - Beware of unlawful wealth as inheritance ... for its spender in righteousness, you suffer and he is happy.
687 - You are counted, by my life, the loser of people in deal ... and most of them in fraud and biting the hand.
688 - Hasten to offer your wealth obediently ... healthy, stingy [with life], desiring provision.
689 - Do not fear missing provision, for Allah guarantees ... provision for you as long as He keeps you today and tomorrow.
690 - Indeed, these monies in the earth are a gift ... like the gift of one who gives bounties and begs.
691 - By it the generous man is known from the ... stingy youth, and the greedy from the ascetic.
692 - Possessors of trusts are known by it ... and every traitor wears affectation.
693 - He shows people doors of asceticism as an ornament ... and strives to acquire the asceticism-inducing debris.
694 - He has leaps in acquiring his debris ... even if he owned the flood, he would not be given drink from thirst.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
695 - Exalted is the Generous Allah that there be seen for Him ... a stingy ally, clutching palm and hand.
696 - The worst of a man's traits is greed and his miserliness ... distances him from Allah, so woe to the distanced.
697 - Indeed, the generous of people is beloved among them ... close to goodness, far from badness.
698 - His generosity covers the man's faults among people ... and miserliness obscures the mention of the noble; keep away.
699 - Hasten to gain heights and leave a youth ... who slackened from heights to gain small amounts.
700 - Wealth is nothing but like shadows in movement ... so hasten to spend before dispersion.
701 - Do not think spending decreases what came ... nor miserliness is bringer of wealth and increase.
702 - Do not hoard lest it be hoarded against you, and spend ... Allah will expand provision for you and you will support.
703 - Do not leave a door of righteousness closed ... you will meet tomorrow the door of satisfaction not locked.
704 - Transferring ownership of a man's wealth during his life ... without compensation is called gifts of generosity.
705 - That, by my life, is a recommended gift ... uniting people despite distance.
706 - It extracts rancor of hearts and plants ... love in them for the generous youth.
707 - Specifying a scholar with it and kinship ... is more pious; and whoever boasts with it, dislike and criticize.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Judiciary, Etiquette of Clothing and Sleep, Wearing Wool and Silk
708 - Be aware that judges are three ... a judge worthy of eternal bliss.
709 - That is one who became knowledgeable of the truth ... and is just in judging cases, so he is guided.
710 - And a judge who became knowledgeable of the rule of truth ... but he is unjust in it and transgresses.
711 - And another judges ignorantly; both ... have the Fire in the text of the correct Hadith.
712 - Every ignorant one regarding judiciary ... it is forbidden for him, so let him be warned and threatened.
713 - Take a path for safety and avoid ... assuming judgeship, protect yourself and retreat.
714 - All mandates of people are regret ... except whom Allah, the Dominant, protects tomorrow.
715 - Sufficient as a deterrent for a youth hoping safety ... is questioning about the flock; understand, be guided.
716 - Did not Umar, the correct scholar, say ... 'I wish I could escape evenly from destruction?'
717 - Be aware that judiciary is a virtue ... and great reward for the supported truthful one.
718 - For enjoining good and uncovering injustice ... and reconciling between people with rebuking the aggressor.
719 - If he expended rightful effort, if correct he wins ... two rewards, and the mistaken has one; emulate.
720 - Forbid bribery for him and accepting it ... and you, to repel injustice, bribe to ransom.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
721 - Clothing of fame is disliked for the wearer ... and what describes skin, not for a husband and master.
722 - If it reveals Awrah to others ... that is prohibited without hesitation.
723 - The best of man's traits combined is moderation of ... matters and a state between worse and better.
724 - Clothing with a living being depicted is forbidden ... embroidery and dye in the most correct of hesitation.
725 - It is disliked in a curtain, ceiling, and wall ... and no harm in what is trodden and pillowed.
726 - It is disliked for a person to prostrate with his face ... on an image depicted in a carpet.
727 - With that, the Grandson of Al-Majd gave fatwa due to its resemblance ... to idol worshippers; prostrate on other than it.
728 - Whatever has a cross depicted is disliked ... and all this for men and buxom women.
729 - Wearing waist-wrappers and leather socks standing is disliked ... likewise touching of two naked in a bed.
730 - And two [women]; and separate in beds between them ... even brothers after ten, be guided.
731 - Say in waking, morning, and evening ... and sleep, from the narrated whatever you wish, be guided.
732 - Whether in travel or residence, do not ... leave the litany of good narrated from Muhammad.
733 - It is good at sleep to shake his bedding ... and sleep on the right and kohl with Ithmid.
734 - Travel barefoot or shod, walk and ride ... live roughly (Tam'adad) and toughen up, and do not get accustomed.
735 - For the servants of Allah are not soft ones ... beware of softness with the dress of deniers.
736 - Be thankful to Allah and satisfied with His portion ... you will be rewarded and increased in provision and spite of enviers.
737 - The longest of a man's tail is to the ankle, and women ... without waist-wrappers a span or cubit to add.
738 - The most noble clothing is to mid-calf ... and what is below ankle, dislike it and raise.
739 - To the wrist was the sleeve of the Chosen One; if loose ... it ended at the tips of his fingers properly.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
740 - For a man, forbid female clothing and vice versa ... due to curse on him, and dislike it remotely.
741 - There is no harm in wearing trousers as covering ... more complete than wrapping; wear it and emulate.
742 - With the Sunnah of Abraham in it and Ahmad ... and his Companions; and make waist-wrappers famous and confirm.
743 - The turban of one leaving his chin empty of turning (Tahanuk) ... according to Ahmad is definitely disliked.
744 - It is good to let the tail hang behind him ... even a span or less according to Ahmad's text.
745 - The best clothing is white for dead ... and living; so whiten absolutely, do not blacken.
746 - There is no harm in dyed [cloth] before washing it ... with ignorance regarding dyes of Jewish people.
747 - It was said: dislike it like used vessels ... and if you know impurity, wash it, be guided.
748 - Deep red and safflower-dyed, dislike ... for men's wear only in Ahmad's text.
749 - Do not dislike in his text what you dyed ... with pure saffron, color of rose.
750 - There is no harm in wearing wool nor the Qaba (outer garment) ... even for women, and the Burnus; understand and emulate.
751 - It is good to clean clothes and fold them ... and wearing your bad [clothes] with long wealth is disliked.
752 - What resembles the Zunnar is disliked absolutely ... and what is disgraceful or resembles Jewish dress.
753 - Dragging clothes for arrogance is forbidden for ... a youth absolutely, but in prayer confirm [prohibition].
754 - What resembles the Zunnar is disliked absolutely ... and there is no harm in tightening the Izar for prostrators.
755 - Forbid wearing silk for every adult ... except for itch, lice, or scabies of deniers.
756 - Permit it in the first, and forbid it in the correct view ... for these boys; from solid [silk] add.
757 - Selling to men for their wearing ... and sewing it and weaving is forbidden in Ahmad's text.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Selling Juice, Grapes, Drinks, Musical Instruments, and Dealing with One Who Mixed Haram
758 - Selling juice to a winemaker is void ... likewise grapes with every aid to a corrupter.
759 - Like a candle for drinkers, and food, and gambling ... nut, chess, and sword for an aggressor.
760 - And tambourine, flute, singing girl ... and Oud; and refrain from leasing that.
761 - Likewise sale of one commanded to strive for Friday [prayer] ... if the second [Adhan] was called; and from him: that which began.
762 - Likewise the ruling regarding what became tight of time for other [prayers] ... and correct from the excused regarding it more firmly.
763 - Leasing dogs and selling them is forbidden ... without dispute with us, not restricted.
764 - Dislike without prohibition is trading with a person ... who acquired wealth from lawful and distressed forbidden.
765 - What is known forbidden of it, forbid; and his lawful ... is permissible; and count his ambiguous among doubtful matters.
766 - Its doubtfulness increases sometimes or decreases ... but reject the buyer's claim of prohibition.
767 - Selling and buying in the place of injustices ... is disliked, or usurpation intending asceticism.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
768 - The wisdom of sale and purchase for the intelligent ... connects the poor to every goal.
769 - Blessed is the Possessor of Rulings and Wisdoms which ... the minds of creation are baffled by, then guided.
770 - In everything is wisdom and indication ... calling to His Oneness and Singularity.
771 - He permitted acquiring wealth from its lawful paths ... so He was the best Guide to its acquisition.
772 - From His wisdom is our initiation and our affairs ... possess connection, not possess singularity.
773 - Every person is not independent in his affair ... so He enacted paths of cooperation for us, be guided.
774 - Sometimes by agency and sometimes by wage ... specified in doing a restricted thing.
775 - Sometimes He permitted ignorance when specification is ... impossible; and from this count Mudaraba.
776 - To Him end the causes in every being ... and from Him all matters end and begin.
777 - He attaches people's hopes to gain ... for which they ride terror in every destination.
778 - Risking himself is easy for this one ... and this one with wealth desiring increase.
779 - To bring provisions whose acquisition is difficult ... to one incapable of them, lying in a bed.
780 - Glory be to Him who initiated and perfected His making ... and Exalted is He above falsehoods of an atheist.
781 - Gifts of our kings are not forbidden ... for Ahmad's Companions accepted from them.
782 - The Chosen One dealt with some Jews ... a youth, and ate when they invited him; so imitate.
783 - Whoever gives charity or returns like ambiguous ... forbidden he has, its remainder is lawful; witness.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Regarding What is Permissible to Wear and What is Forbidden of Silver, Silk, Wearing Rings, Ruling of Gold and Silver Vessels, Disobedience to Parents, and Giving the Road its Right
784 - Forbid for males what they wove from ... silver and pure gold or plated.
785 - Forbidden in Ahmad's text is the waistband of ... silk, likewise a tassel; do not hesitate.
786 - Permissible for males is a silver ring ... and sword decoration with a gold pommel.
787 - And a nose and binding a tooth with it out of necessity ... and Abu Bakr's saying permits the ascetic.
788 - Take two views regarding the youth's belt jewelry ... from white silver, and attribute two aspects.
789 - Silver is permitted in sword sheaths ... and boot, legging, helmet, armor; confirm.
790 - In a curtain or what is a place of disrespect ... writing the Glorified Quran is disliked.
791 - Writing other than it is not disliked ... from Dhikr in what is not trodden and paved.
792 - Scratching off images is permissible for the house renter ... like the bathhouse for the entrant; witness.
793 - Buying a doll without a head is permissible for the orphan's guardian ... if she asks; but with the head, block.
794 - He does not buy what was an image ... from his money, not hers in the abstract [view].
795 - Depicting a living being completely is forbidden ... and count it a major sin for the threat.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
796 - There is no harm in wearing furs and buying them ... skins of lawful [animals], its death not confirmed.
797 - Like meat in the first [view], forbid fox skin ... and from him [Ahmad]: let it be worn, but block prayer in it.
798 - Ahmad disliked sable and fennec fox ... and their squirrel and ermine too; let him increase.
799 - In his text there is no harm in rabbit skin ... and forbid all predators like a cat firmly.
800 - There is no harm in a ring of silver and ... agate and crystal and similar to what is listed.
801 - Brass, lead, and their iron are disliked ... and gold ring is forbidden for males.
802 - It is good in the left like Ahmad and his companions ... and disliked in the middle and index finger of the hand.
803 - Whoever did not remove it entering the toilet ... block writing Quran and Dhikr with it.
804 - Forbid kohl container, probe from cash (gold/silver) ... and decoration of mirror and comb encased.
805 - And decoration of lamp, inkwell, Quran ... saddle and collar for beasts imitated.
806 - Disobedience to parents is a major sin ... so treat them kindly as reward and be praised.
807 - Arrogant walk and its like is disliked ... a place of arrogance except in war against deniers.
808 - Do not dislike drinking standing nor putting on ... shoes for a youth in the most correct confirmed view.
809 - It is good to start putting on shoes with the right ... and reverse in removing; and dislike the reverse, be guided.
810 - A person walking in a single sandal is disliked by ... choice, most correct, even to fix a spoiler.
811 - There is no harm in a sandal you pray in without ... harm, and check them at mosque doors.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
812 - Istirja' (Saying Inna lillahi...) is good when his shoelace breaks ... and restricting barefoot walking to paved roads.
813 - If you find stones one day in the road ... or thorns or bone, remove [them] and likewise the bad.
814 - Be wary of sitting in the road, it was ... forbidden except with conditions numbered.
815 - They are enjoining good and forbidding evil ... and returning Salam to the Muslim initiating.
816 - Lowering gaze and refraining from harm ... and guiding one who seeks directions to a destination.
817 - Ambiguous mud in streets is pure ... otherwise a little of it is pardoned with better [view].
818 - Rain purifies all graves of the ... ancients if no moist bone remains in them.
819 - He wore the Sibti [shoes] which are free ... of hair with his Companions; imitate them.
820 - Sindi sandals are disliked for their vanity ... their squeaking is Jewish fashion, so keep away.
821 - In his text dislike for men and women the ... thin [clothing] except for husband in private and master.
822 - If it reveals Awrah to others ... that is prohibited without hesitation.
823 - Shortening clothing and lengthening it is disliked ... without need out of arrogance and leaving habit.
824 - For men dislike wide collar in his text ... and linen is not disliked in the established [view].
825 - Praising Allah is good in every state ... especially in wearing a new garment.
826 - Say to a brother: Wear out and replace, and the ... God will replace; thus say: Live praiseworthy, be guided.
827 - Whoever is content with lowest clothing in humility ... will be clothed in magnificent garments tomorrow.
828 - Blessed is the Bestower managing His creation ... with what He willed without restricted prevention.
829 - How many wisdoms in the fold of His rulings for Him ... He manages them, clearing hearts so they are guided.
830 - He is not questioned, but questioning ... His creation about what they say tomorrow.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Marriage, Treating the Wife, Etiquette of Intercourse and Apportionment
831 - He permitted the act of marriage for us and enacted it ... for what He willed in us of customary growth.
832 - Our Madhhab is its recommendation, and it is obligatory ... on one fearing hardship, burning [with desire].
833 - Take from an advisor, O my brother, advice ... and be firm and beware with a supported heart.
834 - Do not marry, if you are an old man, a young girl ... you will live a life of harm or accept rejection.
835 - Do not marry one who exceeds you in rank ... you will always be under her rule in distress.
836 - This, by my life, is a summary in conditioning ... compatibility, for in it is perfection of affection.
837 - Do not desire her wealth and furniture ... if you are poor, you will be humiliated and oppressed.
838 - Do not live in her house with her family ... you will hear then types of numbered reminders of favors.
839 - There is no good in one who was in his wife's bounty ... going in humility to her and returning.
840 - Do not deny the giving of little out of distress ... and forgive, you gain reward and good affection.
841 - Do not ask about what you knew and overlook ... faults if the Law did not blame; be guided.
842 - Be mindful that women are trusts ... captives with us; keep the advice of a guide.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
843 - Do not increase denial lest you be accused ... and do not lift the whip from every aggressor.
844 - Do not hope to straighten her crookedness ... for she is nothing but like a repeated rib.
845 - A youth dwelling in a room over a street ... leads to suspicion of the innocent guided one.
846 - Beware, O this one, of the green manure (beautiful woman of bad origin) ... she will return soon to her bad origin.
847 - Forbid for all marrying the one who committed Zina ... until repentance then add expiry of waiting period.
848 - From Ahmad: if the one who committed Zina with her wants her ... his repentance is a condition for a knotted contract.
849 - Do not marry in poverty except for necessity ... and seek refuge in the shield of fasting, you will be guided and directed.
850 - Be aware that women are toys for us ... so improve then whatever you can and do well.
851 - The best of women is who pleased the husband in sight ... and who protected him in absence and presence.
852 - Short of words, short of her house [staying in] ... short of eye glance from every distant one.
853 - Stick to the religious one, you win wishes ... the loving, fertile, of origin, possessor of worship.
854 - Noble of origin from generous ones, you win then ... noble children; and aim for virginity.
855 - One is closer to justice so be content ... and if you wish reach four, do not increase.
856 - Announcing marriage is prescribed and their beating ... for it with a Duff contrary to a corrupter.
857 - Ask the Merciful for her good then seek refuge in Him from ... the harm of her evil at the wedding, be guided.
858 - It is a right on spouses to live together ... with kindness and giving rights not with distress.
859 - Intercourse with a concubine is not lawful nor ... his wife in menstruation and anus; block.
foot_note: 1. This verse does not exist in (Z) and (B), and it is in the printed version and the copy in the handwriting of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Khalaf Al-Dahyan.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
860 - Whoever wishes between the buttocks for pleasure ... if he does not penetrate, he is not distanced.
861 - It was said intercourse is Sunnah once a month ... otherwise in the week if he increases.
862 - Increase is not Sunnah upon him except ... at the urge of desire and seeking offspring.
863 - Say Bismillah and say 'O Allah keep away from us and what ... You provided the Devils'; supplicate for intercourse, be guided.
864 - Increasing speech during intercourse is disliked ... and block his withdrawing before her completion.
865 - It is also prescribed to foreplay before it ... and his intercourse with her naked is disliked.
866 - And a person's Wudu along with washing his private part ... if he desires return is recommended; do well.
867 - Intercourse with the maiden is disliked with another seeing ... even a co-wife consenting and gathering in a bed.
868 - Obligate obedience of enjoyment for the husband ... by angering him, anger is upon her and she is distanced.
869 - Whomever you angered as husband by her disobedience spends the night ... angels of the Merciful cursing her; attribute.
870 - Your permission is recommended for visiting a Mahram ... and her presence for the dead not with strictness.
871 - If she goes out in adornment or perfumed ... she is to be prevented, and if you fear harm prevent and be strict.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
Individual Obligation and Collective Obligation, and Obligation of Advice to Allah, His Messenger, and the Ummah
872 - Be aware that obligations are divided ... into individual like Fasting with prayer of worship.
873 - And collective obligations (Fard Kifaya); when some perform ... it, sin falls from every individual.
874 - Like repelling harm from Muslims for the capable ... like satisfying a hungry deprived poor person.
875 - And covering a naked person, visiting a sick person ... and washing a dead person then burying the interred.
876 - And shrouding him then praying over him with ... following the carried to the grave; be happy.
877 - Among them are industries permitted, important ... for interest people need; be supported.
878 - Farming and planting, digging a river and its well ... and organizing them then block the breaches.
879 - Building a bridge then a wall and repairing them ... and an arch needed then a mosque.
880 - Our Great Imamate, establishing a call ... and repelling doubts of the stubborn misguider.
881 - Jihad and Hajj every year, likewise Judiciary ... and Fatwa and teaching the Glorified Book.
882 - And teaching what the best Messenger enacted ... and all science in Sharia leading to happiness.
883 - Arithmetic and morphology and grammar, reading ... and with language with medicine science; not distanced.
884 - Stick to piety of Allah in every state ... you win the canes of the race today and tomorrow.
885 - And advice to the Book of Allah with advice to Ahmad ... your Prophet, best of Messengers, Muhammad.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
886 - And advice to all Muslims, their leader ... and their subjects; accept the will of a guide.
887 - There ceased not to be Imams among us every era ... defending the religion of guidance with the sword.
888 - Negating the distortion of the deviants and showing the ... correct from the defective in every scene.
889 - So four in the beginning of the matter are a pillar ... and four in the end of the matter; imitate.
890 - Each came in religion with his utmost effort ... and the most praised (Ahmad) of them in critique is the Madhhab of Ahmad.
891 - Due to excessive following of the Prophet and his Companions ... so for this reason he did not respond to a threatener.
892 - They called him to the saying of misguidance but he did not answer ... and replied to them the reply of the best guided one.
893 - He gave himself to support the truth patiently ... over flogging and threat from every aggressor.
894 - He returned by Allah's praise with victory and guidance ... and they returned with loss and eternal humiliation.
895 - The outcome continued to be for whoever feared [Allah] ... such is Allah's promise in the Most Glorious Remembrance.
896 - Beware of opinions of every embellisher ... of his speech, for poison is within it, the bad.
897 - The best of people died and the religion is complete ... rich without need for clarification from any atheist.
898 - The seeker of true religion in opinion is lost ... and whoever delved into Ilm al-Kalam was not guided.
899 - Sufficient deficiency for them is the contradiction of their speech ... and each says 'The truth is with me', so imitate.
900 - Had it been truth, it would not be contradictory ... nor would its owner shift, confused.
901 - Truth is nothing but its night is like its day ... removing light free of hesitation.
902 - By it the heart is reassured not shaken ... nor fearful but safe from distress.
903 - Whoever imitates opinions strays from guidance ... and whoever imitates the Infallible in religion is guided.
904 - Religion is nothing but following what came ... from Allah and the Bashir Guide Muhammad.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
905 - Thus said Al-Shafi'i and others ... of the supporters of truth from every guided one.
906 - Pure reception with acceptance for it without ... interpretation or likening or rejection of deniers.
907 - So struggle until you convey to the self its excuse ... and be in acquiring knowledge a climber of highlands.
908 - Do not let life go from you in vain ... and do not be cheated in the two blessings, but strive.
909 - Whoever abandons pleasures attains wishes and whoever ... devotes to pleasures bites on the hand.
910 - In suppressing souls' desires is their glory ... and in attaining what they desire is eternal humiliation.
911 - Do not busy yourself except with what earns heights ... and do not accept for the precious soul the bad.
912 - In a person's solitude with knowledge is his comfort ... and a person's religion is safe in isolation.
913 - He is safe from gossip and from harm of ... a sitter and from a hateful slanderer and enviers.
914 - Be a saddle (companion) of the house, for it covers a fault ... and is the youth's fortress from every deviator and corrupter.
915 - The best companion of a man is books benefitting him ... sciences and manners like a supporting intellect.
916 - Mix if you mix with every successful one ... of scholars, people of piety and correctness.
917 - He benefits you with knowledge and forbids you from desire ... so accompany him, you will be guided by his guidance and directed.
918 - Beware of the backbiter if you leave him and the ... foul-mouthed, for a person imitates a person.
919 - Do not accompany fools, for the person of ignorance if he intends ... reform of a matter, O brother of firmness, corrupts.
920 - The best companions with your Lord are their best ... to his companion, and the neighbor is like what I began.
foot_note:
1. In (Z) and (B): (Sitter), and affirmed from the printed version and copy (A). 
2. In (Z) and (B): (Mocker), and affirmed from (A), the printed version and Ghidha' al-Albab.

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
921 - The best place you stood in and ornament ... you adorned with is remembrance of the God in a mosque.
922 - Restrain your tongue from defect and let it be ... always moist with remembrance of Allah, O my companion.
923 - Fortify all limbs from obscenity ... they will be for you on the Day of Recompense best witnesses.
924 - Persist in studying the Quran for it ... softens a heart hard like rock.
925 - Maintain doing obligations on time ... and take a share in darkness of Tahajjud.
926 - Call if you stand in the night a Hearer ... Near, Responsive, beginning with favors.
927 - Extend to Him the palm of your poverty humbly ... with a penitent heart and call, you will be given and guided.
928 - Do not get bored of knowledge and stay up to attain it ... without boredom you praise the journey's travel tomorrow.
929 - Be patient with poverty and wear contentment ... with what the Merciful decreed and thank Him and praise.
930 - Glory is only in contentment and satisfaction ... with lowest obtained sufficiency and asceticism.
931 - Whoever sufficiency does not satisfy, there is no way ... to his satisfaction; so be content and aim.
932 - Whoever seeks richness, Allah enriches him; and richness ... is richness of soul not abundance of numbers.
933 - Do not seek knowledge for money and showing off ... for the crux of the matter is in good intent.
934 - Be acting upon knowledge in what you can ... so the person who imitates you is guided by you.
935 - Keen on benefitting people and their guidance ... you attain every good in eternal bliss.
936 - Beware of vanity and arrogance, you attain ... misery in both abodes; so be guided and guide.
foot_note:
1. In (Z) and the printed version: (You praise). 
2. In (Z) and the printed version: (Happiness).

book_title: The Millennium in Legal Manners [Famous as 'Manzumat al-Adab']
text:
937 - Here I have expended advice to my effort and indeed I ... admit my shortcoming and by Allah I am guided.
938 - It is completed, and praise be to Allah alone ... in every state always, not restricted.
939 - A bride surpassing the morning sun, Hanbali ... wrapping with clear light and wearing it.
940 - If she attributes herself in knowledge, her attribution is ... to a Mujtahid in supporting religion, imitated.
941 - Imam of Guidance, Ornament of the Pious, Ibn Hanbal ... upon his love for Allah I am deposited in a grave.
942 - No garden surrounded by the light of its spring ... with its sweet cool limpid water.
943 - Is better than its verses and issues ... enclosed by it one day without hesitation.
944 - Take it by study, not by sleep you attain ... for people of piety and knowledge in every scene.
945 - Do not refrain from memorizing it, for it is a pearl ... unique, I extracted it in critique.
946 - Purest blessings of Allah, Exalted is His praise ... and Mighty, upon the best of creation Muhammad.
947 - And his Companions and the noble of his Family and who ... followed them in goodness, by them he remained imitating.
foot_note:
1. This verse does not exist in (B) and (Z). 
2. I finished caring for this poem and comparing it with its originals on Tuesday the twenty-ninth of Muharram in the Hanbali Mosque in Salihiyah, Damascus, may Allah populate it with knowledge and faith, during one of my trips to protected Damascus. And blessings of Allah be upon our Prophet Muhammad and his family and companions and peace. Muhammad bin Nasir Al-Ajmi.
